{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{Year nav topic5|1470|architecture}} {| class="infobox" |- style="background-color:#f3f3f3" | align="center" | [[1460s in architecture|1460s]] · '''1470s in architecture''' · [[1480s in architecture|1480s]] |- | align="center" | [[Architecture timeline]] |} __TOC__
==Buildings== * 1470 – [[:File:Leuchtturm Westkapelle 1.jpg|Church and lighthouse tower]], [[Westkapelle, Netherlands#Two lighthouses|Westkapelle]], [[Walcheren]], completed * 1471 – [[Provand's Lordship]], [[Glasgow]], [[Scotland]], built * 1472–1474 – The Ordos Wall, first substantial section of the [[Ming Great Wall]] of China, built * 1475–1479 – [[Dormition Cathedral, Moscow]], designed by [[Aristotele Fioravanti]], built * 1479 – [[Munich Frauenkirche]] completed by [[Jörg von Halsbach]]
==Births== [[File:Provand's Lordship, Glasgow.jpg|thumb|[[Provand's Lordship]]]] * 1475: March 6 – [[Michelangelo]], born Michelangelo di Lodovico Buonarroti Simoni in [[Caprese Michelangelo|Caprese]], [[Tuscany]], Italian sculptor, painter, architect, poet and engineer (died [[1564 in architecture|1564]]) * 1475: September 6 – [[Sebastiano Serlio]] born in [[Bologna]], Italian Mannerist architect and theoretician working in France (died c. [[1554 in architecture|1554]])
==Deaths== * 1472: April 25 – [[Leon Battista Alberti]], Italian architect and polymath (born [[1404 in architecture|1404]]) * 1472? – [[Michelozzo]], Florentine architect and sculptor (born c. [[14th century in architecture|1396]])
[[Category:15th-century architecture|*]] [[Category:1470s works|Architecture]]

{{Year nav topic5|1596|literature}} This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1596'''.
==Events== *February – [[James Burbage]] buys the disused [[Blackfriars Theatre]] from Sir William More for £600, but is prevented from using it for theatre by the opposition of wealthy influential neighbors. *[[June 22]] – [[Henry Carey, 1st Baron Hunsdon|Lord Hunsdon]] dies; his place as [[Lord Chamberlain]] will be taken by [[William Brooke, 10th Baron Cobham]], who is sympathetic to the [[Puritans]] and hostile to the [[English Renaissance theatre]]. With Cobham's allowance, [[Thomas Skinner (Lord Mayor of London, 1596)|Thomas Skinner]], [[Lord Mayor of the City of London]] bans players from the City and tears down the [[Inn-yard theatre|inn-theatres]], the [[Inn-yard theatre|Bel Savage Inn]], the [[Inn-yard theatre|Cross Keys Inn]], and others. Cobham dies the next year, 1597. *The first complete edition of ''[[The Faerie Queene]]'' is published in six books. *The novel ''[[Jin Ping Mei]]'' (金瓶梅, The Plum in the Golden Vase) by "Lanling Xiaoxiao Sheng" circulates in manuscript in China.
==New books== <!-- (''Title of published book translation''), ("Title of published poem/story translation"), (Literal translation of title) --> ===Prose=== *[[Thomas Harriot]] – ''Brief and True Report of the New Found Land of Virginia'' *[[Richard Johnson (16th century)|Richard Johnson]] – ''The Famous Historie of the Seaven Champions of Christendom''
===Drama=== *Anonymous – ''Captain Thomas Stukeley'' *[[William Burton (antiquary, died 1645)|William Burton]] – ''De Amoribus Perinthii et Tyanthes'' *[[George Chapman]] – ''[[The Blind Beggar of Alexandria]]'' *[[Antoine de Montchrestien]] – ''Sophonisbe'' *[[Lope de Vega]] **''Los comendadores de Córdoba'' **{{Lang|es|Los donaires de Matico}} **''[[:es:El marqués de Mantua|El marqués de Mantua]]'' **''El remedio en la desdicha'' *[[Thomas Kyd]] (probably, perhaps with Shakespeare) – ''[[Edward III (play)|The Raigne of King Edward the Third]]'' (published) *[[William Shakespeare]] – ''[[Henry IV, Part 1]]''
===Poetry=== {{Main|1596 in poetry}} *[[Thomas Campion]] – ''Poemata'' *[[Bartholomew Griffin]] – ''Fidessa'' *[[Francisco Rodrigues Lobo]] – ''Romances'' *[[Thomas Nashe]] – ''Have With You to Saffron Walden'' *[[Edmund Spenser]] – ''Colin Clouts Come Home Againe''
==Births== *[[March 31]] – [[René Descartes]], French philosopher (died [[1650 in literature|1650]]) *[[August 18]] – [[Jean Bolland]], Flemish Jesuit writer (died [[1665 in literature|1665]]) *September **[[Moses Amyraut]], French Protestant theologian (died [[1664 in literature|1664]]) **[[James Shirley]], English dramatist (died [[1666 in literature|1666]]) *[[September 4]] – [[Constantijn Huygens]], Dutch poet (died [[1687 in literature|1687]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[Lucas Holstenius]], German humanist (died [[1661 in literature|1661]]) *''Probable year of birth'' – [[Udriște Năsturel]], Wallachian scholar and poet (died c. [[1658 in literature|1658]])
==Deaths== *[[February 17]] – [[Friedrich Sylburg]], German classical scholar (born [[1536 in literature|1536]]) *[[February 19]] – [[Blaise de Vigenère]], French cryptographer, diplomat, scientist, and author (born [[1523 in literature|1523]]) *August – [[Hamnet Shakespeare]], son of William (born [[1585 in literature|1585]]) *[[October 3]] – [[Florent Chrestien]], French writer (born [[1541 in literature|1541]]) *November – [[George Peele]], dramatist (born [[1556 in literature|1556]]) *[[November 1]] – [[Pierre Pithou]], French lawyer and scholar (born [[1539 in literature|1539]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[Jean Bodin]], French political philosopher (born [[1530 in literature|1530]]) *''Probable year of death'' – [[Henry Willobie]], English poet (born [[1575 in literature|1575]])
==References== {{reflist}}

{{refimprove|date=November 2015}} '''The aestheticization of politics''' was an idea first coined by [[Walter Benjamin]] as being a key ingredient to [[Fascist]] regimes.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Jay|first=Martin|year=1992|title="The Aesthetic Ideology" as Ideology; Or, What Does It Mean to Aestheticize Politics?|journal=Cultural Critique|publisher=University of Minnesota Press|issue=21|jstor=1354116}}</ref> In this theory, life and the affairs of living are conceived of as innately [[art]]istic, and related to as such politically. [[Politics]] are in turn viewed as artistic, and structured like an [[art form]] which reciprocates the artistic conception of life being seen as art.
This has also been noted as being connected to the [[Italy|Italian]] [[Futurism (art)|Futurist]] movement and postulated as its main motivation for getting involved in the Fascist regime of [[Italy]].
Alternately, "[[politicization of aesthetics]]" (or "politicization of art") has been used as a term for an [[ideology|ideologically]] opposing synthesis, sometimes associated with the [[Soviet Union]], wherein art is ultimately subordinate to political life and thus a result of it, separate from it, but which is attempted to be incorporated for political use as theory relating to the consequential political nature of art. The author [[Emilio Gentile]] has stressed that these two ideas are not mutually exclusive, and both regimes had a large degree of the other. In Benjamin's original formulation, however, the politicization of aesthetics was treated conceptually as the polar opposite of the aestheticization of politics, the former treated as a kind of revolutionary praxis, redeeming force, or "antidote" to the corrupting fascistic influence of the latter.
==See also==
*''[[The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction]]'' *[[The arts and politics]] *[[Art for art's sake]] *[[Aestheticization of violence]]
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{Use British English|date=March 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Alex Crawford
{{post-nominals|country=GBR|OBE}} | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1963|04|15|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Nigeria]] | nationality = British | occupation = [[Correspondent|Foreign correspondent]] | spouse = Richard Edmondson (4 children) }} '''Alex Christine Crawford''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|OBE}} (born 15 April 1963){{Citation | last = | first = | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Birthdays | newspaper = [[The Guardian]] | pages = 35 | year = | date = 15 April 2014 | url = }} is a British journalist who currently works as a Special Correspondent for [[Sky News]] based in [[South Africa]].{{cite web|url=http://skynews.skypressoffice.co.uk/biographies/foreign-correspondents/alex-crawford |title=Alex Crawford |publisher=Sky News |accessdate=22 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130101140402/http://skynews.skypressoffice.co.uk/biographies/foreign-correspondents/alex-crawford |archivedate=1 January 2013 }}{{cite web|title=Alex Crawford, RTS Journalist of the Year, Posted to Sky News’ South Africa Bureau |url=http://skynews.skypressoffice.co.uk/press-releases/items/2011-04/2024/alex-crawford-rts-journalist-year-posted-sky-news%E2%80%99-south-africa-bu |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130421105737/http://skynews.skypressoffice.co.uk/press-releases/items/2011-04/2024/alex-crawford-rts-journalist-year-posted-sky-news%E2%80%99-south-africa-bu |dead-url=yes |archive-date=21 April 2013 |date=27 April 2011 |publisher=skypressoffice.co.uk |accessdate=27 December 2012 }}{{London Gazette |issue=60009 |date=31 December 2011 |page=9 |supp=y }} ==Career== Crawford first worked in journalism at the ''Wokingham Times'', completing a [[National Council for the Training of Journalists]] newspaper course in [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]] while working there. She subsequently worked for the [[BBC]] and for [[TV-am]] before joining Sky News when it was launched in 1989.{{cite news |url=http://www.nctj.com/news-and-events/news/three-time-rts-winner-is-mays-alumnus-month |title=Three time RTS winner is May's alumnus of the month |publisher=National Council for the Training of Journalists |date=3 May 2011 |accessdate=22 August 2011}}{{cite web|title=Alex Crawford OBE |url=http://www.arts.ac.uk/alumni/in-the-news/honoraryawards2012/alexcrawfordcbe/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130419092925/http://www.arts.ac.uk/alumni/in-the-news/honoraryawards2012/alexcrawfordcbe/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=19 April 2013 |publisher=arts.ac.uk |accessdate=22 December 2012 }}{{cite web|title=HarperCollins Author Profile: Alex Crawford|url=http://www.harpercollins.co.uk/Authors/11223/alex-crawford|publisher=harpercollins.co.uk|accessdate=22 December 2012}} She began working as a foreign correspondent for Sky News in 2005. Crawford has reported on the Gulf, the Middle East and more recently has covered the [[Arab Spring]] uprisings in [[Tunisia]], [[Egypt]], [[Bahrain]] and [[Libya]]. She has been named Journalist of the Year on five occasions by the [[Royal Television Society]] and was appointed [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] (OBE) in the 2012 New Year Honours for services to broadcast journalism. Her work has been recognized by the Foreign Press Association in 2007, 2008, 2009 and 2010. She has also been cited by the Bayeux War Correspondents Awards for her reports from hostile environments for every year since 2007. === Coverage of the Libyan civil war === Crawford covered the [[2011 Libyan civil war]]. She was widely praised for her live on-scene reporting of the [[2011 Battle of Tripoli|Battle of Tripoli]]. She was the first TV journalist to enter Libya with the rebels, becoming a face of the conflict. She travelled with a rebel convoy into the heart of Tripoli, shooting direct live footage of the rebel advances, which reached [[Martyrs' Square, Tripoli|Green Square]] with little resistance from pro-Gaddafi forces. She wore a helmet and bulletproof vest, stating that she did not feel in any danger, but wore them as a precaution against celebratory gunfire.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/aug/22/libya-sky-alex-crawford | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Patrick | last=Foster | title=Libya coverage: Sky's Alex Crawford scoops her rivals | date=22 August 2011|accessdate=22 December 2012}}{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/aug/22/alex-crawford-sky-reporter-libya | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Leo | last=Hickman | title=Alex Crawford is our new journalistic hero | date=22 August 2011|accessdate=22 December 2012}}{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8714868/Libya-Sky-News-reporter-Alex-Crawford-praised-for-dramatic-Tripoli-reporting.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Andrew | last=Hough | title=Libya: Sky News reporter Alex Crawford praised for dramatic Tripoli reporting | date=22 August 2011|accessdate=22 December 2012}}{{cite news|author=Erik Wemple|title=Alex Crawford explains her safety gear |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/erik-wemple/post/alex-crawford-explains-her-safety-gear/2011/08/22/gIQAUFMaWJ_blog.html | work=The Washington Post | date=22 August 2011|accessdate=22 December 2012}}{{cite news|author=Jesse Emspak |title=Laptop, cigarette lighter aid reporter in Libya|url=http://news.discovery.com/tech/laptop-cigarette-lighter-aid-reporter-libya-110822.html|date=22 August 2011|publisher=news.discovery.com|accessdate=22 December 2012}}{{cite news|author=Alex Farber|title=Sky News' Alex Crawford praised for Libyan reports|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/news/broadcasters/sky-news-alex-crawford-praised-for-libyan-reports/5031059.article|date=22 August 2011|publisher=broadcastnow.co.uk|accessdate=22 December 2012}}{{subscription required}} She also covered the raid of [[Bab al-Azizia]] live from outside the compound, and was one of the first journalists to go inside once the raid was over. === Coverage of the Northern Mali conflict === Crawford was active in covering the [[Northern Mali conflict]] from 15 January 2013 until the end of French military operations.{{cite news|title=Mali Conflict: France Recaptures Diabaly|url=http://news.sky.com/story/1040841/mali-conflict-france-recaptures-diabaly|date=21 January 2013|publisher=news.sky.com|accessdate=27 January 2013}} Her [[Sky News]] team was the first to enter [[Timbuktu]] after it was liberated by French forces. == Personal life == Crawford was born in [[Nigeria]] in 1963 to a Chinese mother and a Scottish father.''Desert Island Discs''. BBC Radio 4. First broadcast 10 January 2016. She was brought up in Nigeria, [[Zambia]] and [[Zimbabwe]] and educated at [[Cobham Hall School]] in [[Kent]].{{cite web|title=Elders' News|date=17 January 2013|url=http://www.cobhamhall.com/elders/elders-news/|quote=Alex Crawford (special correspondent for Sky News) was appointed an OBE for services to broadcast journalism in January 2012. In February she was also awarded the Royal Television Society Television Journalist of the Year Award for the third straight year. This is the fourth time she has won this award.|publisher=Cobham Hall School|accessdate=3 March 2012}} She currently lives in Johannesburg, South Africa with her husband, sports journalist Richard Edmondson, and four children.{{cite news|last=Darrall|first=Stephanie|title=War reporter? My kids wish I was a dinner lady, says Alex Crawford|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2031020/War-reporter-My-kids-wish-I-dinner-lady-says-Alex-Crawford.html|accessdate=27 December 2012|newspaper=Daily Mail|date=29 August 2011}}{{cite news|last=McGrath|first=JA|title=Edmonson's absence will be keenly felt|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/horseracing/2369678/Edmonsons-absence-will-be-keenly-felt.html|accessdate=27 December 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=13 December 2005}}{{cite news|last=Edmondson|first=Richard|title=Richard Edmondson: Nothing angers my wife more than sexists who question her career|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/commentators/richard-edmondson-nothing-angers-my-wife-more-than-sexists-who-question-her-career-2345510.html|accessdate=27 December 2012|newspaper=The Independent|date=29 August 2011}}{{cite news|last=Tyzack|first=Anna|title=My Perfect Weekend: Alex Crawford|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/my-perfect-weekend/8927944/My-Perfect-Weekend-Alex-Crawford.html|accessdate=27 December 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=1 December 2011}} == Publications == *''Colonel Gaddafi's Hat''. London: Collins, 2012. {{ISBN|9780007467303}} *''How to Survive in a War Zone''. London: Collins, 2012. {{ISBN|9780007506972}} == See also == * [[War correspondent]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Twitter}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Crawford, Alex}} [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:British people of Chinese descent]] [[Category:British television journalists]] [[Category:Officers of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:People educated at Cobham Hall School]] [[Category:WFTV Award winners]]

{{Refimprove|date=May 2016}}
An '''animateur''' is a [[music]]al professional whose role is to engage audiences with a new or unfamiliar form of music,<ref name="mediamatch" /> "bringing it to life" beyond what might be expected in a traditional performance.
The role of animateur developed from the French concept of "animation socio-culturelle" and first became established in the 1980s as musical outreach activities were being formalised in the UK.<ref name="Higgins2012" /> Because the role has roots in the United Kingdom,<ref name="polyphonic" /> they are most common in the English-speaking world.
While an animateur is likely to have some skill in performance (with voice or instrument), conducting, teaching and possibly composition or arrangement, their principal role is to assist the communication of the performers and the audience. If working with a [[symphony orchestra]], for instance, they might accomplish this through running participatory workshops to introduce audience members to aspects of the music to be performed, or by facilitating dialogue between performers and audience members.
There are animateurs in a wide number of musical styles. While they are probably most common in [[classical music]], they also work in [[jazz]], [[gamelan]] and some forms of African traditional music. Often they are employed by an orchestra, concert hall or music education service, though some also work freelance accepting commissions from groups or organisations for a specific occasion. Animateurs also work with children (where the discipline can approach a form of musical [[youth work]]) as well as adults. Possibly the best known animateur in the United Kingdom is [[Gareth Malone]], who for some years ran the youth and community choirs at the [[London Symphony Orchestra]]'s music education center, [[LSO St Luke's]] prior to applying the same skills in a series of television programmes.
==References== {{Reflist|refs= <ref name="mediamatch">{{cite web | url=http://www.media-match.com/uk/music/jobtypes/animateur-jobs-407859.php | title=Animateur | publisher=Media Match | accessdate=24 May 2016}}</ref> <ref name="polyphonic">{{cite web | url=http://www.polyphonic.org/article/an-animateur%E2%80%99s-journey-a-report-from-the-field/ | title=An Animateur’s Journey: A report from the field | publisher=Polyphonic | date=17 September 2007}}</ref> <ref name="Higgins2012">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kA7TfA_iPiMC|title=Community Music: In Theory and In Practice|last=Higgins|first=Lee|date=2012-07-09|publisher=Oxford University Press, USA|isbn=9780199777839|language=en}}</ref> }}
[[Category:Occupations in music]]

revision.comment: Fixed the first spelling of her name. (Neither her own English-language web page, nor the rest of this page, have diacritical marks in the English-language spelling of her name)
revision.text:
{{Short description|American painter}} {{Infobox person | name = <!-- include middle initial, if not specified in birth_name -->Anna A. Frants | image = A frants by UG.jpg | alt = Anna Frants | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1965|10|01}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = multimedia artist, curator, collector | awards = Autodesk Planet Studio Award, New York | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = | father = Aleksandr Solomonovich Pinsker, political commentator ([[Voice of America]]) | website = http://www.annafrants.net }} '''Anna Frants''' ({{lang-ru|А́нна Алекса́ндровна Фра́нц}}; born 1 October 1965<ref>[https://www.facebook.com/anna.frants.9/about?lst=100001044284519%3A1513421078%3A1532006556 About Anna Frants] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180720131606/https://www.facebook.com/anna.frants.9/about?lst=100001044284519%3A1513421078%3A1532006556 |date=2018-07-20 }} // Facebook.</ref><ref>[http://famous-birthdays.ru/data/01_oktyabrya/frantz_anna_aleksandrovna.html Франц Анна Александровна] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180719173439/http://famous-birthdays.ru/data/01_oktyabrya/frantz_anna_aleksandrovna.html |date=2018-07-19 }} // Famous Birthdays.ru.</ref> in [[Leningrad]], [[Soviet Union]]) is an American [[multimedia artist]], [[curator]], and art [[Collecting|collector]]. She is the founder of nonprofit cultural foundation "St. Petersburg Arts Project" and "CYLAND" MediaArtLab, and is director of "Frants Gallery" ([[New York City|New York]], [[United States]]).
== Biography == In 1989, Frants graduated from the [[Saint Petersburg Art and Industry Academy|St. Petersburg Stieglitz State Academy of Art and Design]] (formerly the Vera Mukhina Leningrad Higher School of Art and Industry), where she had majored in [[Industrial Design]]. In 1992, she was admitted to the New-York [[Pratt Institute]] to the department of Art and Design where she majored in [[Computer Graphics]] and [[Animation]].<ref>[http://www.ncca.ru/events.text?filial=6&id=3946 Лекция Анны Франц «Дизайн против Искусства против Дизайна»] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180407184129/http://www.ncca.ru/events.text?filial=6&id=3946 |date=2018-04-07 }} // [[National Centre for Contemporary Arts]].</ref>
The mastering of [[computer graphics]] and [[animation]] marked the beginning of her enthusiasm for [[new media]], [[new media art]] and technologies in art<ref name="auto">[http://digicult.it/it/news/the-time-keeper-a-traveling-group-exhibition-examining-the-presence-of-past-present-and-future/ The Time Keeper. Una mostra di gruppo itinerante Feed dei commenti] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171003175048/http://www.digicult.it/it/news/the-time-keeper-a-traveling-group-exhibition-examining-the-presence-of-past-present-and-future/ |date=2017-10-03 }} // DIGICULT. Digital Art, Design and Culture. 2012.06.12.</ref> and the concentration of her interests on the transition from traditional classical methods to [[cyberarts]] that was afforded unlimited possibilities by the rapidly developing [[internet]].
In 1997, she married Leonid Frants. Their son Daniil became the youngest artist at CYLAND MediaArtLab: when he was only twelve, he created, as part of Cyfest, an international educational game program for children, the workshop "Humanizing Robots",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/humanizing.robots|title="Humanizing Robots" by Daniil Frants - global workshop on robots for kids|website=www.facebook.com|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref> which he held in [[Russia]], [[Germany]], [[Japan]], [[United States]] and [[Ukraine]].
In addition to continuous exhibition activities as an artist and a curator<ref name="auto1">[http://www.chasedmagazine.com/2015/07/people-interview-with-curator-anna-frants-at-venice-biennal-2015/ People: Interview with curator Anna Frants at Venice Biennial 2015] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180304173629/http://www.chasedmagazine.com/2015/07/people-interview-with-curator-anna-frants-at-venice-biennal-2015/ |date=2018-03-04 }} // Chased. Magazin für Kunst, Ausstellungen, Vernissagen in Berlin. July 12. 2015.</ref> in New York, [[St. Petersburg]], [[Europe]] and [[Japan]], in 2010, Anna traveled to the [[Polar regions of Earth|Polar Region]] as a member of the international group of artists within the program "The Arctic Circle"<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.thearcticcircle.org/ |title=The Arctic Circle artist and scientist residency program |access-date=2014-02-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140206201610/http://www.thearcticcircle.org/ |archive-date=2014-02-06 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> organized by the [[Canadian government]]. The program's purpose was to afford the artists an opportunity to visit hard-to-reach places of the [[Polar regions of Earth|Polar Region]] that are mostly known through scientific reports, which would subsequently allow them to create art projects based on their impressions of the region. In addition to the video footage filmed by Anna, that trip resulted in her interactive project Trembling Creatures,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.annafrants.net/home_19.html|title=::: Anna Frants :::|website=www.annafrants.net|accessdate=20 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170929000534/http://www.annafrants.net/home_19.html|archive-date=29 September 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> exhibited at the group show of participants of those annual expeditions that opened in May 2014 at the "1285 Avenue of the Americas Art Gallery"<ref>[http://dutchcultureusa.com/blog/1631/paul-segers-and-arjen-de-leeuw-in-magnetic-north-artists-and-the-arctic-circle Paul Segers and Arjen de Leeuw in 'Magnetic North Artists and The Arctic Circle'] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171018190505/http://dutchcultureusa.com/blog/1631/paul-segers-and-arjen-de-leeuw-in-magnetic-north-artists-and-the-arctic-circle |date=2017-10-18 }} // Dutch Culture USA. 16 May 2014, by Stefanie Hofman.</ref> in New York.
== Selected exhibitions == * Weather Forecast: Digital Cloudiness - Reggia di Caserta, Italy, 2018. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://cyland.org/lab/cyfest-continues-at-the-eighteenth-century-residence-in-caserta-italy/|title=CYFEST Continues at the Eighteenth-Century Royal Palace in Caserta, Italy - CYLAND|website=cyland.org|accessdate=20 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180720131606/http://cyland.org/lab/cyfest-continues-at-the-eighteenth-century-residence-in-caserta-italy/|archive-date=20 July 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * Personal Spaces – Interactive Multimedia Works by Anna Frants, Carla Gannis, Alexandra Dementieva, Elena Gubanova and Ivan Govorkov. [[National Arts Club]], 15 Gramercy Park South, New York, 2018 * HYBRIS, Monsters and Hybrids in Contemporary Art, University Ca’ Foscari, Venice, 2017]. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://cyland.org/lab/hybris-exhibition-in-venice/|title=HYBRIS Exhibition in Venice, Monsters and Hybrids in Contemporary Art - CYLAND|website=cyland.org|accessdate=20 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171207110234/http://cyland.org/lab/hybris-exhibition-in-venice/|archive-date=7 December 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * Patterns of the Mind, Convergence, London, 2016. <ref>{{Cite web |url=https://archive.is/j7CIA |title=Convergence Digital Art Partnership|work=www.convergence-london.com|access-date=2017-09-28 }}</ref> * Nargifsus, Transfer Gallery, New York, 2016. <ref>{{Cite web |url=http://newhive.com/peertospace/nargifsus |title=Archived copy |access-date=2017-09-28 == Curatorial activities == The most notable of Frants' curatorial works were the retrospective exhibitions "Sterligov's Group", 2006, New York, and "Art around the Barracks", 2003, New York.
In the documentary of [[Andrei Zagdansky|Andrey Zagdansky]] "Konstantin and Mouse", dedicated to [[Konstantyn K. Kuzminsky|Konstantin Kuzminsky]], one of the episodes was filmed at the opening night of "Art around the Barracks" at Frants Gallery in [[Soho]].
Among contemporary artists, who constantly collaborate with Anna Frants as a curator, are [[Vitaly Pushnitsky]], Elena Gubanova and Ivan Govorkov, Alexander Kozhin, Alexander Terebenin, Marina Koldobskaya, Alexandra Dementieva, Peter Belyi, Petr Shvetsov.<ref name="auto1"/>
== CYLAND MediaArtLab ==
In 2006, Anna Frants together with [[:ru:|Колдобская, Марина Дмитриевна|Marina Koldobskaya]] founded the international media lab "СYLAND".
Since 2007, the MediaArtLab holds the annual festival of cyberart "Cyfest", the largest cyberart festival in Eastern Europe featuring artists from different countries who share an enthusiasm for new technologies.<ref name="auto2">[http://veniceconference.com/speakers/anna-frants Anna Frants] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180304174152/http://veniceconference.com/speakers/anna-frants |date=2018-03-04 }} // Venice Conference 2017.</ref><ref name="auto1"/>
{{Cquote |text=''The use of computers allows the artist to break away from the deterministic nature of traditional art forms... Computer art is often similar to conceptual art from the point of view of intellectual judgment: the viewer needs to understand the artist's intentions. This understanding is even more important in interactive projects because the way we react depends on our ability to understand the artist's idea and expectations. The cyberart is challenging because it is based on the technologies and the means that are less intuitive for us and new in their form... Each innovative work gives us a new perspective for understanding the infinitely expanding universe of art and teaches us to understand its creative glossary.'' |source=<ref>Citation from a booklet of Anna Frants exhibition «Visual Dreams №2391-95. VideoCyberArt» — Borey Gallery ([[St. Peterburg]]), December 2011.</ref> }}
== Nonprofit foundation "St. Petersburg Arts Project" == In 1999, Anna and Leonid Frants created the nonprofit foundation "St. Petersburg Arts Project"<ref name="artpropaganda.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.artpropaganda.com/|title=St. Petersburg Arts Project non-for-profit foundation New York|website=www.artpropaganda.com|accessdate=20 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180411192756/http://www.artpropaganda.com/|archive-date=11 April 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> that is still active. Its purpose was the representation in New York<ref name="auto"/> of the artists from [[St. Petersburg|Leningrad/St. Petersburg]] who have been working there from the postwar 1950s until the present time.<ref name="auto2"/> The primary focus was on the so-called Leningrad underground<ref>Л. Гуревич. Художники ленинградского андеграунда. Биографический словарь. Искусство. СПб, 2007.</ref> — the unique and underexplored cultural phenomenon of the 1970s and the artistic and social environment that brought if forth.
Gradually, the scope of activities of "Frants Gallery Space" expanded and started including not just the traditional genres, such as painting, sculpture and graphics, but also the art associated with the latest technologies:<ref name="artpropaganda.com"/> cyberart, video art, computer animation, interactive installations as well as performance art.
== Collection == The collection's creation was a natural extension of the development of "St. Petersburg Arts Project". Since 1998, Anna and Leonid Frants have been collecting works of visual arts of Leningrad underground.<ref name="auto2"/> Their current collection also includes sculptures, assemblages, photographs, videos, objects of actual art and archival materials.
In January 2013, the Department of Contemporary Art at the [[Hermitage Museum]] organized, as a part of the project "Actual Art of St. Petersburg, A Retrospective",<ref>{{cite web|url= https://archive.is/wSlne|title=Простые правила В рамках образовательной программы "РЕТРОСПЕКТИВА. Страницы истории петербургского искусства"|work=Hermitage Museum|accessdate=July 20, 2018}}</ref> the exhibition "Simple Rules".<ref>[http://obtaz.com/hermitage_private_collections_02.htm "Simple Rules" exhibition in Hermitage] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170214191808/http://obtaz.com/hermitage_private_collections_02.htm |date=2017-02-14 }} // Obtaz Atrs.</ref> It showcased works from Russian and foreign private collections.

[[Image:Apollo Barberini Glyptothek Munich 211.jpg|thumb|right|220px|The “Apollo Barberini”]] The '''Apollo Barberini''' is a 1st–2nd-century Roman sculpture of [[Apollo Citharoedus]]. It is a probable copy of the sculpture of [[Apollo Citharoedus]] (possibly by [[Scopas]] and perhaps from the sanctuary of Apollo at [[Rhamnus (Greek archaeological site)|Rhamnus]], in Attica) that was the cult statue in the [[temple of Apollo Palatinus]] in [[Rome]].
It is named after the [[Barberini]] who acquired it. It is now held in the [[Glyptothek|Munich Glyptothek]] (Inv. 211).
==See also== Other items from the Barberini collections: *[[Barberini Faun]] *[[Portland Vase]]
==Sources== *[https://www.jstor.org/stable/505329 Linda Jones Roccos, 'Apollo Palatinus: The Augustan Apollo on the Sorrento Base', ''American Journal of Archaeology'', Vol. 93, No. 4 (Oct., 1989), pp. 571-588]
{{sculpture-stub}} [[Category:Sculptures of Apollo]] [[Category:Barberini collection]] [[Category:Roman copies of Greek sculptures]] [[Category:Archaeological discoveries in Italy]] [[Category:Musical instruments in art]]

[[File:Becket casket.jpg|thumb|The Becket Casket, about 1180–90, Limoges, France, V&A Museum no. M.66-1997]] [[File:Reliquary Thomas Becket MNMA Cl23296.jpg|thumb|A simpler, slightly later chasse showing scenes of Beckett's life.]]
The '''Becket Casket''' is a [[reliquary]] in [[Limoges enamel]] now in the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]]. It is made of [[gilding|gilt-copper]] round a wooden core, decorated with [[champlevé]] [[Vitreous enamel|enamel]], and of a shape called a "[[chasse (casket)|chasse]]". It was made in about 1180–90 in [[Limoges]], France, and depicts one of the most infamous events in [[England|English]] history. On the night of 29 December 1170, [[Archbishop]] [[Thomas Becket]] was murdered in [[Canterbury cathedral]] by four knights obeying the wishes of [[Henry II of England|King Henry II]]. It provoked outrage throughout [[Europe]], and pilgrims flocked to Canterbury to pray at the site of the murder. In 1173 Becket was [[saint|canonized]] and his shrine was one of the most famous in the Christian world, until its total destruction in 1538 during the reign of [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]]. It is thought that this particular casket was made to hold the relics of Thomas Becket that were taken to Peterborough Abbey (now [[Peterborough Cathedral]]) by Abbot Benedict in 1177. Benedict had been Prior at Canterbury Cathedral and therefore saw Becket's assassination.
[[Relic]]s of St Thomas were widely dispersed in the years following his death. Many were placed in [[casket]]s made in [[Limoges enamel]] in south-west [[France]]. This was the centre for the production of objects in champlevé enamel, which is characterized by brilliant blues, colourful rosettes and boldly engraved figures. This casket is the most elaborate, the largest and possibly the earliest in date, but over 45 medieval chasses survive showing Becket's story and thought to have been made in Limoges. Another fine example is in the [[Burrell Collection]] in [[Glasgow]].<ref>Binski, 225, with a catalogue entry on the Burrell chasse.</ref>
The scene of the [[martyr]]dom is shown on the front, where one of the knights decapitates Becket in front of the [[altar]], while on the sloping roof the archbishop's funeral is depicted. On the back are four saints and at the one end [[Jesus Christ|Christ]] is seated on a rainbow. The other end, which may have shown [[St Peter]], is missing, as is the floor of the casket and its contents.

==External links== *[https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O80222/casket-the-becket-casket/ The Becket Casket at the Victoria and Albert Museum]

{{Unreferenced|date=March 2007}} [[Image:AlexanderNevskyCathedral-Sofia-6.jpg|thumb|[[Alexander Nevsky Cathedral, Sofia]], by [[Alexander Pomerantsev]]]] [[Image:Naval Cathedral of St Nicholas in Kronstadt 02.jpg|thumb|[[Naval Cathedral in Kronstadt|Naval Cathedral of Saint Nicholas in Kronstadt]], by [[Vasily Kosyakov]]]] The '''Byzantine Revival''' (also referred to as '''Neo-Byzantine''') was an [[Revivalism (architecture)|architectural revival]] movement, most frequently seen in religious, institutional and public [[building]]s. It incorporates elements of the [[Byzantine style]] associated with [[Eastern Christian|Eastern]] and [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox Christian]] architecture dating from the 5th through 11th centuries, notably that of [[Constantinople]] (present-day [[Istanbul]]) and the [[Exarchate of Ravenna]]. Neo-Byzantine architecture emerged in the 1840s in [[Western Europe]] and peaked in the last quarter of the 19th century in the [[Russian Empire]], and later [[Bulgaria]]. Neo-Byzantine school was active in [[Yugoslavia]] between [[World War I]] and [[World War II]].
==German countries== [[Image:Favoriten (Wien) - Christuskirche (1).JPG|thumb|right|Christuskirche in [[Matzleinsdorf Protestant Cemetery]], Vienna 1858—1860]] Earliest examples of emerging Byzantine-[[Romanesque architecture]] include the [[Alexander Nevsky Memorial Church]], Potsdam, by Russian architect [[Vasily Stasov]], and the [[St. Boniface's Abbey, Munich|Abbey of Saint Boniface]], laid down by [[Ludwig I of Bavaria]] in 1835 and completed in 1840. The basilica followed the rules of 6th-century [[Ravenna]] architecture, although its [[corinthian order]] was a clear deviation from the historical Byzantine art. In 1876 [[Ludwig II of Bavaria]] commissioned Neo-Byzantine interiors of the externally Romanesque [[Neuschwanstein Castle]], complete with mosaic images of [[Justinian I]] and Greek saints.
Danish architect [[Theophil Hansen]] became a supporter of the style in the 1850s. His major works belonged to [[Neo-Grec]] style, however, Hansen as a professor of Byzantine art in [[University of Vienna]] shaped a generation of architects that popularized Neo-Byzantine architecture in [[Austro-Hungary]], [[Serbia]] and post-war [[Yugoslavia]]. Hansen's own Neo-Byzantine work include the [[Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church, Vienna]] (1856—1858) and the Christuskirche in [[Matzleindorf]] (1858—1860).
Several Neo-Byzantine-style churches were constructed during the [[Gründerzeit]], for instance, the [[Sacred Heart Church (Berlin)|Sacred Heart Church]] or the [[Rosary Basilica (Berlin)|Rosary Basilica]], both located in [[Berlin]].
==Russian Empire==
{{main|Neo-Byzantine architecture in the Russian Empire}}
[[Sophia Cathedral]] in [[Pushkin (town)|Pushkin]] (1782—1788) was the earliest and isolated experiment with Byzantine treatment of otherwise [[neoclassicism|neoclassical]] structures. In 1830s [[Nicholas I of Russia]] promoted the so-called ''Russo-Byzantine'' style of churches designed by [[Konstantin Thon]]. Nicholas I despised true Byzantine art; Thon's style in fact had little common with it. Notably, Thon routinely replaced the circular Byzantine arch with a [[keel]]-shaped [[gable]], and the hemispherical Byzantine dome with an [[onion dome]]; layout and structural scheme of his churches clearly belonged to neoclassical standard.
True Byzantine art, popularized by [[Grigory Gagarin]] and [[David Grimm (architect)|David Grimm]], was adopted by [[Alexander II of Russia]] as the de facto official style of the Orthodox Church. Byzantine architecture became a vehicle of Orthodox expansion on the frontiers of Empire ([[Congress Poland]], [[Crimea]], the [[Caucasus]]). However, few buildings were completed in the reign of Alexander II due to financial troubles. [[Alexander II of Russia|Alexander III]] changed state preference in favor of [[Russian Revival]] trend based on 16th-17th century [[Moscow]] and [[Yaroslavl]] tradition, yet Byzantine architecture remained a common choice, especially for large cathedrals. Neo-Byzantine cathedrals concentrated in the western provinces (Poland, Lithuania), the Army bases in Caucasus and [[Central Asia]], the [[Cossack host]]s and the industrial region in [[Urals]] around the city of [[Perm]]. Architects [[David Grimm (architect)|David Grimm]] and [[Vasily Kosyakov]] developed a unique national type of a single-dome Byzantine cathedral with four symmetrical [[pendentive]] apses that became de facto standard in 1880s-1890s.
The reign of [[Nicholas II of Russia|Nicholas II]] was notable for the architects's turn from this standard back to [[Hagia Sophia]] legacy, peaking in the [[Naval Cathedral in Kronstadt]] and [[Poti]] cathedral. These designs employed [[reinforced concrete]] that allowed very fast construction schedule; their interiors contained clear references to contemporary [[Art Nouveau]] yet the exteriors were a clear homage to medieval Constantinople. Russian Neo-Byzantine tradition was terminated by the [[Russian revolution of 1917|revolution of 1917]] but was continued by emigrant architects in [[Yugoslavia]] and [[Harbin]]. <center> <gallery> File:Kronstadt Naval Cathedral.jpg|[[Naval Cathedral in Kronstadt|Naval Cathedral]], [[Kronstadt]] File:Kazan church in Voskresensky Novodevichy monastery (from cemetery).JPG|The Kazan church, [[Novodevichy Cemetery (Saint Petersburg)|Novodevichy Cemetery]], [[St. Petersburg]] File:Север России (175).JPG|[[Ioannovsky Convent]], St. Petersburg File:Novosibirsk ANevsky Cathedral 07-2016 img1.jpg|[[Alexander Nevsky Cathedral, Novosibirsk]] File:Вознесенский собор.jpg|[[Novocherkassk Cathedral]] File:Krestovosdvizenskiy sobor.JPG|St. Nicholas Monastery, [[Verkhoturye]] File:Kharkov002.jpg|[[Annunciation Cathedral, Kharkiv]] File:Sevastopol 04-14 img09 Vladimir Cathedral.jpg|[[St. Vladimir's Cathedral, Sevastopol]] File:Novoafonsky monastyr.jpg|[[New Athos Monastery]], [[New Afon]] File:St. Volodymyr's Cathedral in Kiev.jpg|[[St Volodymyr's Cathedral]], [[Kiev]] File:Pareizticigo Kristus dzimšanas Rigas katedrale.jpeg|[[Nativity Cathedral, Riga]] File:Kauno soboras. 2007-04-06.jpg|[[St. Michael the Archangel Church, Kaunas]] File:Znamenskaya cerkov Vilnius.JPG|The church of the [[Theotokos]] [[Orans]] ([[Our Lady of the Sign Church, Vilnius|Our Lady of the Sign]]), [[Vilnius]] File:Cerkiew prawosławna w Białowieży 02.jpg|The Orthodox Church in [[Białowieża]] File:Cerkiew Aleksandra Newskiego w Łodzi.jpg|[[Alexander Nevsky Cathedral, Łódź|Alexander Nevsky Cathedral]], [[Łódź]] File:Poti Cathedral (Photo A. Muhranoff, 2011)-1.jpg|[[Poti Cathedral]] File:Alexander_Nevsky_Cathedral,_Tbilisi_(ტფილისის_სამხედრო_ტაძარი).jpg|[[Alexander Nevsky Cathedral, Tiflis]]
</gallery> </center>
==United States==
In the United States and elsewhere, the Neo-Byzantine style is often seen in [[Vernacular architecture|vernacular]] amalgamations with other [[Medieval]] revivalist styles such as [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] and [[Gothic revival|Gothic]], or even with the [[Mission Revival Style architecture|Mission Revival]] or [[Spanish Colonial Revival Style architecture|Spanish Colonial Revival]] styles.
Notable [[United States|American]] examples include many buildings on the campus of [[Rice University]] in [[Texas]], and [[Christ Church United Methodist]] in Manhattan by [[Ralph Adams Cram]]; [[Immaculate Conception Church (New Orleans)|Immaculate Conception Church]] in [[New Orleans]], [[St. Francis de Sales Roman Catholic Church (Philadelphia)|St. Francis de Sales Church]] in [[Philadelphia]], [[Cathedral Basilica of St. Louis]] and the [[Basilica of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception]] built between 1920 and 1959 in [[Washington, D.C.]] In the early 1980s, [[Philip Johnson]] designed a [[Post-Modernist]] addition to the [[Cleveland Play House]] that reflects Byzantine influences, and could thus be termed Neo-Byzantine.
==United Kingdom and Ireland== [[Westminster Cathedral]] (1895–1903), the Catholic cathedral in London, is the largest and most thorough British effort in the style, by [[John Francis Bentley]] (1839–1902), but there are a number of other churches and other buildings such as the [[Christ Church, Brixton Road]], also in London, by [[Arthur Beresford Pite]], 1897–1903, near the [[Oval Cricket Ground]]. From about 1850 to 1880 in [[Bristol]] a related style known as [[Bristol Byzantine]] was popular for industrial buildings which combined elements of the [[Byzantine style]] with [[Moorish architecture]]. [[Newman University Church]], [[Dublin]] (1885–86) is a notable Irish example.

{{Infobox company | name = C3 Presents | logo = C3presents_logo.png | logo_size = 100px | caption = | type = | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = {{Start date|2007}} | founder = Charles Attal, Charlie Jones and Charlie Walker | defunct = | location_city = [[Austin, Texas]] | location_country = [[United States]] | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = | industry = Concert promotion, event production and artist management | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|C3Presents.com}} | footnotes = | intl = }} '''C3 Presents''' is a concert promotion, event production and artist management company based out of [[Austin, Texas]].[https://www.c3presents.com/ C3 Presents] C3 also produces several iconic multi-day festivals including Austin City Limits Music Festival in Texas,[https://www.aclfestival.com/ ACL Music Festival] Voodoo Music + Arts Experience in New Orleans,[https://www.voodoofestival.com/ Voodoo Festival] and Lollapalooza in Chicago along with its six international editions.[https://www.lollapalooza.com/ Lollapalooza] ==History== C3[https://www.austinchronicle.com/news/2010-10-08/big-dogs-young-rebels-and-aging-giants/ Austin Chronicle Blog] was founded by Charles Attal, Charlie Jones and Charlie Walker in 2007(2)[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/07/arts/music/07lolla.html NY Times] and headquartered in Austin, TX, with offices in Los Angeles, Atlanta, and New Orleans. The company also promotes more than 1,100 concerts annual in arenas, casinos and clubs throughout North America. In the Fall of 2014, Live Nation began talks to purchase a 51% stake in the Austin company’s events production and promotions businesses.[https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/6414053/live-nation-completes-deal-for-c3-presents Live Nation Completes Deal][https://www.austinchronicle.com/daily/music/2015-02-26/c3-presents-and-live-nation-team-up/ C3 and LiveNation Team Up][https://consequenceofsound.net/2014/12/live-nation-acquires-controlling-interest-in-lollapaloozaacl-promoter-c3-presents/ Consequence Of Sound] At the time, C3 was largest independent concert promoter in the world.[https://www.bizjournals.com/austin/blog/at-the-watercooler/2014/12/live-nation-buys-ownership-stake-in-austins Live Nation buys ownership stake] The deal was completed in December of that year. ==Events== Annually, C3 Presents produces the following festivals: • All Things Go Fall Classic[https://www.allthingsgofallclassic.com All Things Go]
• Auckland City Limits Music Festival [https://www.aucklandcitylimits.com Auckland City Limits Music Festival]
• Austin City Limits Music Festival [https://www.aclfestival.com/ ACL Music Festival]
• Austin Food + Wine Festival [https://www.austinfoodandwinefestival.com/ Austin Food + Wine Festival ]
• Chipotle Cultivate Festival [http://eventintelligencegroup.com/chipotle-cultivate-kansas-city-bbq-and-counting-people/ Chipotle Cultivate]
• In Bloom Music Festival (formerly FPSF) [https://www.inbloomfestival.com/ In Bloom Music Festival]
• Innings Music Festival [https://www.inningsfestival.com/ Innings Music Festival]
• Lollapalooza Argentina [https://www.lollapaloozaar.com/ Lollapalooza Argentina]
• Lollapalooza Berlin [https://www.lollapaloozade.com/ Lollapalooza Berlin]
• Lollapalooza Brazil [https://www.lollapaloozabr.com/ Lollapalooza Brazil]
• Lollapalooza Chicago [https://www.lollapalooza.com/ Lollapalooza]
• Lollapalooza Chile [https://www.lollapaloozacl.com/ Lollapalooza Chile]
• Lollapalooza Paris [https://www.lollaparis.com/ Lollapalooza Paris]
• Lollapalooza Stockholm [https://variety.com/2018/music/news/lollapalooza-stockholm-sweden-to-launch-in-2019-1202825166/ Lollapalooza Stockholm]
• Music City Food + Wine Festival [https://www.musiccityfoodandwinefestival.com/ Music City Food + Wine Festival]
• Music Midtown [https://www.musicmidtown.com/ Music Midtown]
• NFL Draft [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/29/sports/football/persistent-mayor-gets-his-pick-nfl-draft-comes-to-chicago.html NFL Draft]
• Shaky Beats Music Festival [https://www.shakybeatsfestival.com/ Shaky Beats Music Festival]
• Shaky Knees Music Festival [https://www.shakykneesfestival.com/ Shaky Knees Music Festival]
• Sydney City Limits Music Festival [https://www.sydneycitylimits.com/ Sydney City Limits Music Festival]
• Voodoo Music + Arts Experience [https://www.voodoofestival.com/ Voodoo Festival]
• Obama Election Night Celebration (2008 and 2012) [https://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/touring/1276167/c3-presents-to-provide-services-for-obama-concert-parade C3 Presents To Provide Services]{{cite web|author1=Ray Waddell|title=C3 Presents To Provide Services For Obama Concert, Parade|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/touring/1276167/c3-presents-to-provide-services-for-obama-concert-parade|website=Billboard Biz|publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=25 January 2015|date=16 January 2009}}{{cite web|author1=Jack Goodall|title=BaROCK Obama’s Inauguration|url=http://www.thembj.org/2009/03/barock-obama’s-inauguration/|website=The Music Business Journal|publisher=[[Berklee College of Music]]|accessdate=25 January 2015|date=March 2009}}
• Obama White House Easter Egg Roll [https://www.pollstarpro.com/NewsContent.aspx?cat=&com=1&ArticleID=812013 PollstarPro] C3 also books and promotes over 1,000 shows nationwide, including Austin venues [[Stubb's BBQ]], [[Emo's]] and La Zona Rosa. ===Artist management=== In addition to promotion and production, C3 Presents also has an artist management division operating in New York City, Los Angeles, Nashville, and Austin. C3 Management has a current roster of over 50 musicians {{Cite web |url=http://www.c3presents.com/artistmanagement.aspx# |title=C3 Presents Clients |access-date=2010-12-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101121064721/http://www.c3presents.com/artistmanagement.aspx# |archive-date=2010-11-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }} including The Strokes, Phoenix, Lindsey Buckingham, My Bloody Valentine, The Head And The Heart, The Revivalists, Justice, Sylvan Esso, and Gramatik.[https://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/legal-and-management/5869579/matt-shay-joins-c3s-management-division Matt Shay Joins] The company also maintains its own freestanding radio promotion, film/TV, digital, and creative staffs.[https://www.pollstarpro.com/NewsContent.aspx?cat=&com=1&ArticleID=812013 PollstarPro] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Talent and literary agencies]]

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''The Seven Books of the Diana''''' (Spanish: ''Los siete libros de la Diana'') is a [[pastoral]] romance written in Spanish by the Portuguese author [[Jorge de Montemayor]]. The romance was first published in 1559, though later editions expanded upon the original text. A sixteenth-century bestseller, the ''Diana'' helped launch a vogue for stories about shepherds, shepherdesses, and their experiences in love. One of its most famous readers was [[William Shakespeare]], who seems to have borrowed the Proteus-Julia-Sylvia plot of ''[[The Two Gentlemen of Verona]]'' from Felismena's tale in the ''Diana''. ==Plot== The ''Diana'' begins with a summary of previous events, telling us that the shepherd Sireno is in love with the shepherdess Diana. She once returned his love, but when Sireno was called away from their village, she was married to another shepherd named Delio. The story begins with Sireno's return after a year's absence, having already learned of Diana's marriage. Over the course of the first three books, Sireno encounters other shepherds and shepherdesses who sing songs and tell stories of their own experiences with frustrated love. Among these is a warrior maiden named Felismena (not truly a shepherd, but dressed as one for the time being), who rescues Sireno and his friends from an attack by wild men. The group of shepherds is persuaded to seek out the enchantress Felicia, who may have the power to solve their romantic dilemmas. In the fourth book they are welcomed by Felicia at her castle, and proceed to tour the wonders within (including the halls of Venus and Mars, and a performance by the legendary Orpheus). After they have rested, Felicia administers her magic potion, causing some of the shepherds to either forget or reroute their old desires. Sireno is cured of his love for Diana. In the final three books the initial love stories are resolved, with the shepherds either finding new love partners or recovering ones they believed they had lost. Felismena finds her lover, Don Felis (or "Felix" in the English translation), and rescues him from an attack by enemy knights. With a little help from Felicia's magic, Felis remembers his love for Felismena and the two are married. The Sireno-Diana situation, however, remains unresolved. Sireno can now greet Diana with calm indifference, but Diana is clearly pained by his transformation and laments her forced marriage to another man. The book ends by promising a sequel, though Montemayor never lived to complete one. ==Expansions and sequels== The 1561 edition of Valladolid introduced certain changes into the text which were often reproduced in later editions and translations. The most significant of these changes is the insertion of a new interpolated tale, the "Abencerraje," told to entertain the shepherds in Felismena's palace at the end of book 4. Scholars now believe the new material to be Montemayor's own work, though the decision to add them to his pastoral romance may have been made by an enterprising publisher.Juan Montero, "Prólogo," in ''La Diana'', by Jorge de Montemayor (Barcelona: Crítica, 1996), lxxx-lxxxi, and p. 213 note 245. Montemayor's text prompted two separate sequels in Spanish, both published in 1564: Alonso Pérez's ''La Segunda Parte de la Diana'' (The Second Part of the Diana), and [[Gaspar Gil Polo]]'s ''Diana Enamorada'' (Enamoured Diana). Bartholomew Yong's English translation of the ''Diana'' (completed ca. 1582 and published in 1598) included both sequels alongside Montemayor's original.''Diana of George of Montemayor'', trans. Bartholomew Yong (London: Edm. Bollifant, 1598). ==Circulation and Influence in the Renaissance== While inspired by Jacobo Sannazaro's [[Arcadia (poem)|''Arcadia'']], Montemayor's ''Diana'' is arguably the first major work of pastoral prose fiction in the Renaissance, placing just as much emphasis on its ongoing plot and interwoven stories as on the poems sung by its shepherd protagonists.Paul Alpers, ''What is Pastoral?'' (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1996), 348-360. The ''Diana'' is significant for being one of the most popular works of early modern fiction not merely in Spain, but abroad as well. By Julián Arribas' count, there were at least thirty-one Spanish editions of the text printed in the sixteenth century alone. That same period also witnessed twelve French translated editions, and one English translation by [[Bartholomew Yong]].Julián Arribas, “Estudio Bibliográfico: Catalogo de Ejemplares,” in ''Los Siete Libros De La Diana'', by Jorge de Montemayor (London: Tamesis, 1996), 19-83. Felismena's back-story in the ''Diana'', wherein Felismena cross-dresses as a page in order to pursue her faithless lover, was probably Shakespeare's source for his [[Two Gentlemen of Verona]].Geoffrey Bullough, ''Narrative and Dramatic Sources of Shakespeare'' (London : New York: Routledge and Paul; Columbia University Press, 1957), volume 1, p. 205-206. Montemayor's ending differs from Shakespeare's play, however, since Montemayor's heroine saves her lover's life; the rekindling of their love is also helped along by Felicia's magic. Speaking more broadly, Geoffrey Bullough, Judith Kennedy, and Stuart Gillespie have all noted that Montemayor's pastoral romance seems to have been foundational for the development of Shakespeare's comedies: they point particularly to Montemayor's influential exploration of love, his emphasis on strong female heroines and their perspectives, and his treatment of amorous intrigue and entanglements.Bullough 205; Judith M. Kennedy, "Introduction," in ''A Critical Edition of Yong’s Translation of George of Montemayor’s Diana and Gil Polo’s Enamoured Diana'', (Oxford: Clarendon P, 1968), p. lii - liii; and Stuart Gillespie, "Shakespeare's Reading of Modern European Literature," in ''Shakespeare and Renaissance Europe'', ed. Andrew Hadfield and Paul Hammond (London: Arden Shakespeare, 2005), p. 103-104. Montemayor's ''Diana'' was also a major inspiration for [[Philip Sidney]] in writing the [[New Arcadia#The New Arcadia|''New Arcadia'']]. Montemayor's influence was noticed early on by Sidney's contemporaries: as John Hoskins stated in 1599, "For the web, as it were, of [Sidney's] story, he followed three: Heliodorus in Greek, Sannazarius' ''Arcadia'' in Italian, and ''Diana'' by Montemayor in Spanish."John Hoskins, ''Directions for Speech and Style'' [1599] (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1935), 41. Sidney in particular seems to have modeled his opening scene between the shepherds Strephon and Klaius on Montemayor's Sireno and Sylvano.Victor Skretkowicz, "General Introduction," in Philip Sidney, ''The Countess of Pembroke’s Arcadia'' (The New Arcadia), ed. Victor Skretkowicz (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1987), p. xix. [[Miguel de Cervantes]] mentions the ''Diana'' with both approval and criticism in the book-burning episode of his ''[[Don Quixote]]'' (part I, chapter 6), where Quixote's friend the priest declares the book too good to be thrown in the fire like the rest:
And opening one, [the priest] saw that it was ''Diana'', by Jorge de Montemayor, and he said, believing that all the others were of the same genre: "These do not deserve to be burned like the rest, because they do not and will not cause the harm that books of chivalry have, for they are books of the understanding and do no injury to anyone. [...] To begin with Montemayor's ''Diana'', I am of the opinion that it should not be burned, but that everything having to do with the wise Felicia and the enchanted water, and almost all the long verses, should be excised, and let it happily keep all the prose and the honor of being the first of such books."Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra, ''Don Quixote'', trans. Edith Grossman (New York: Ecco, 2003), p. 50.
==Translations== ''Diana'' has been translated into English twice. First by Bartholomew Yong in 1598, (republished in 1968){{Citation | last = Montemayor | first = Jorge de | translator = Bartholomew Yong | editor-last = Kennedy | editor-first = Judith M. | title = A critical edition of Yong's translation of George of Montemayor's Diana and Gil Polo's Enamoured Diana | place = Oxford | publisher = Clarendon Press | date = 1968 }} and more recently by RoseAnna M. Mueller in 1989.{{Citation | last = Montemayor | first = Jorge de | translator = RoseAnna M. Mueller | title = The Diana | place = Lampeter, Dyfed, Wales | publisher = Edwin Mellen | isbn =0-88946-735-8 | date = 1989 }} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Early Modern literature]] [[Category:Spanish literature]]

[[File:Toilet water bottles.JPG|thumb|right|<center>Bottles of eau de toilette</center>]]
'''Eau de toilette''' ({{IPA-fr|o d(ə) twalɛt|lang}}) literally translated as '''toilet water''' (but more appropriately described as "grooming water") is a lightly scented [[eau de cologne|cologne]] used as a skin freshener.<ref>[http://www.thefreedictionary.com/toilet+water The Free Dictionary definition]</ref><ref>[http://www.macmillandictionary.com/thesaurus/british/rose-water/rose-water_3/Perfume MacMillan Dictionary]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/toilet-water|title=Definition of "toilet water"|work=[[Collins English Dictionary]]|accessdate=27 November 2015}}</ref>{{refn|group=n|In this context, "toilette"/"toilet" has its older meaning of [[personal grooming]]; the name predates [[toilet|the modern sense of "toilet"]], which was originally [[euphemism|euphemistic]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Murray|first=James|authorlink=James Murray (lexicographer)|title=Oxford English Dictionary|edition=1st|chapterurl=https://archive.org/stream/oedxaarch#page/n119/mode/1up|volume=Vol.10 Part 1: Ti–U|year=1926|publisher=Clarendon Press|location=Oxford|page=108|chapter=toilet ''sb.'' §§7,9b}}</ref>}} It is also referred to as '''"aromatic waters"''' and has a high alcohol content.<ref>Cristiani, p. 117</ref> It is usually applied directly to the skin after bathing or shaving.<ref>[http://www.proz.com/kudoz/english/cosmetics_beauty/2455435-toilet_water.html toilet water term meaning]</ref><ref>[http://www.antiquebottles.com/poch/15.html Distinguishing Colognes, Perfumes, Scents, & Toilet Waters]</ref> It was originally composed of alcohol and various [[volatile oils]].<ref>Cox, p. 118</ref> Traditionally these products were named after a principal ingredient; some being geranium water, lavender water, lilac water, violet water, spirit of myrcia and 'eau de Bretfeld'.<ref>Ebert, p. 304</ref> Because of this, eau de toilette was sometimes referred to as "toilet water".<ref>Lawless, p. 39</ref>
In modern perfumery, the term eau de toilette is generally used to describe the concentration of fragrance, with eau de toilette being weaker than [[Perfume|Eau de Parfum]] and stronger than [[Eau de Cologne]].<ref name="BS Lacey">{{cite web|last1=Lacey|first1=Miriam|title=Fragrance Defined: Parfum vs. EDP vs. EDT vs. Cologne|url=http://www.bellasugar.com/Eau-de-Toilette-Eau-de-Parfum-Parfum-What-Mean-19193129|website=bellsugar.com|publisher=Bell Sugar|accessdate=27 July 2014}}</ref><ref name="GL 2010">{{cite web|last1=Aug 8 2010|title=What is the difference between eau de parfum and eau de toilette in perfumes and colognes?|url=http://www.gildedlife.com/2010/08/what-is-the-difference-between-eau-de-parfum-and-eau-de-toilette-in-perfumes-and-colognes/|website=gildedlife.com|publisher=Gilded Life|accessdate=27 July 2014}}</ref>
== Types == [[File:Perfume formulas 1910.jpg|thumb|right|Perfume formulas 1910]]
Eau de toilette is a weaker concentration of fragrance than pure perfume.<ref>Baker, p. 262</ref><ref>Fettner, p. 102</ref> The concentration of aromatic ingredients is typically as follows (ascending concentration): * Splash and After shave: 1–3% [[aromatic compound]]s * [[Eau de Cologne]] (EdC): Citrus type perfumes with about 2–6% perfume concentrate aromatic compounds<ref>{{cite web|title=Cologne|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/125986/cologne|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica}}</ref> * Eau de Toilette (EdT): 5–15% (typical ~10%) aromatic compounds * Eau de Parfum (EdP), Parfum de Toilette (PdT): 10–20% (typical ~15%) aromatic compounds. Sometimes listed as "eau de perfume" or "millésime". * Perfume extract (Extrait): 15–40% ([[International Fragrance Association|IFRA]]: typical 20%) aromatic compounds
Perfume oils are often diluted with a solvent, though this is not always the case, and its necessity is disputed. By far the most common solvent for perfume oil dilution is ethanol or a mixture of ethanol and water. Perfume has a mixture of about 10–20% perfume oils mixed with alcohol (acting as a diffusing agent delivering the fragrant odor) and a trace of water. Colognes have about 3–5% perfume oil mixed with 80–90% alcohol with about 5 to 15 percent water in the mix. Originally, [[eau de cologne]] was a mixture of citrus oils from such fruits as lemons, oranges, tangerines, limes, and grapefruits. These were combined with such substances as lavender and [[neroli]] (orange-flower oil). Toilet water has the least amount of perfume oil mixture among the three main liquid "perfumery" categories. It has only about 2 to 8 percent of some type of perfume oil and 60–80% alcohol dispersent with water making up the difference.<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/perfume perfume]</ref><ref name="Groom329">Groom, p. 329</ref> Toilet waters are a less concentrated form of these above types of alcohol-based perfumes.<ref>[http://www.thefreedictionary.com/eau+de+toilette ''eau de toil'' definition from the online Free Dictionary]</ref><ref>[http://thesaurus.com/browse/toilet+water Thesaurus online dictionary]</ref> Traditionally cologne is usually made of citrus oils and fragrances, while toilet waters are not limited to this specification.<ref>Grolier, p. 154</ref><ref>''Consumer reports'', pp. 409–411</ref>
== History == In the fourteenth century Hungarian Eau de toilette, predecessor of [[eau de cologne]], was produced.<ref>Müller, p. 348</ref> [[Elisabeth of Poland, Queen of Hungary|Queen Elisabeth of Hungary]] (1305–1380) had created a fragrant oil mix with alcohol that evaporated slowly on her skin.<ref name="Sherrow125"/> [[Hungary Water]] was the first toilet water developed.<ref name="Stoddart154"/> This toilet water was called "eau de la reine de hongrie", and was based on rosemary.<ref name="HistoryofPerfume">[http://www.everythinkaboutperfume.com/history.html The History of Perfume] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150208043220/http://www.everythinkaboutperfume.com/history.html |date=2015-02-08 }}</ref>
King of France [[Louis XIV]] (1638–1715) used a concoction of scents called "heavenly water" to perfume his shirts; It consisted of [[Agarwood|aloewood]], [[musk]], [[Orange (fruit)|orange flower]], [[rose water]] and other [[spice]]s.<ref name="Sherrow125">Sherrow, p. 125 ''King Louis XIV (1638–1715) had his shirts scented with toilet water that included aloewood, rosewood, orangle flower, musk, and spices. The concoction was called "heavenly water" ...''</ref>
Some Eau de toilette were once considered restorative skin toners with medical benefits.<ref>Better Nutrition magazine, Nov 1999, p. 34</ref><ref>Hiss, pp. 918–919</ref><ref>Frank, p. 414</ref> The journal [[Medical Record (journal)|Medical Record]] reported in 1905 that a toilet water spray restores energies lost in business, social, and domestic situations.<ref>Dewey, p. 55</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=bclNAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA333&dq=perfume+%22toilet+water%22+define&hl=en&ei=mId1TJbbMIGclgfV1-zJBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CGAQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=perfume%20%22toilet%20water%22%20define&f=false Interstate druggist, Volume 7, page 333]</ref> During the fourteenth through sixteenth centuries a type of toilet water called "plague waters" was supposed to drive away the [[bubonic plague]].<ref name="Stoddart154">Stoddart, p. 154</ref><ref>[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=58687 Dictionary of Traded Goods and Commodities, 1550–1820 by Nancy Cox and Karin Dannehl]</ref>
==Varieties== * [[Carmelite Water]] – a toilet water of lemon balm, orange flower, angelica root, and spices prepared for [[Charles V of France]], first made in 1379 by the nuns of a [[Carmelites|Carmelite]] abbey.<ref>Booth, p. 157</ref><ref name="homemade">[https://archive.is/20070614152057/http://www.readersdigest.ca/homegarden/n_homegarden_fragrance.html Reader's Digest – Make your own Fragrance]</ref><ref>Halpern, p. 37</ref><ref>Booth, p. 82</ref> * Carnation Toilet Water – extract of Jasmine 2.5 pints, extract of Orange Flower 2.5 pints, extract of Rose 5 pints, tincture of Vanilla 20 ounces, Oil of Pink (synthetic) 2 ounces.<ref>Lillard, p. 33</ref> * Creole Toilet Water – to 6.75 ounces of orris root cut in small pieces put 1.5 pint of French brandy. Allow this mix to stand for 2 weeks, stirring frequently. Then filter the mix and add 3 pints of French brandy and 3 drops of oil of orange blossoms. Add 0.75 fluid ounce of oil of geranium. Distill and add a little coumarin essence.<ref name="Hopkins875">Hopkins, p. 875</ref> * Eau de lavand ambre – a favorite with Spanish women who use it in their hair as well as on the skin after bathing.<ref>Fletcher, p. 219</ref> * [[Florida Water]] – based on the nineteenth-century formula for a commercially prepared toilet water that mixes floral essential oils.<ref>Miller, p. 99</ref> * Geranium Toilet Water – oil of rose geranium, 2 ounces; tincture of orris root, 2 ounces; tincture of musk, 1 drop; rose water, 8 ounces: alcohol, 4 pints.<ref name="Hopkins875"/> * Heliotrope Toilet Water – heliotropine, 2 drops; [[rose oil]], 15 [[Minim (unit)|minims]]; [[bergamot orange|bergamot oil]], a half drop; neroli oil, 5 minims; alcohol, 10 ounces; water, 6 ounces.<ref>Hopkins, p. 876</ref> * Honey water<ref name="Groom329"/> – an old-time English toilet water. The [[British Pharmaceutical Codex]] gives the formula.<ref>Hiss, p. 915</ref> * Jasmine toilet water – made with spirits of cologne, jasmine, and alcohol.<ref>[http://chestofbooks.com/food/household/Housekeeper-Encyclopedia/Toilet-Ideas-Part-2.html Toilet Water ideas]</ref> * [[Kananga Water]] – is a "holy water" used for purification in revival ceremonies.<ref>[http://privatewww.essex.ac.uk/~patrickp/papers/RecentJCwords.html#k kananga water ]</ref> * Lavender water<ref name="Groom329"/><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=rahakHd9V2oC&pg=PA73&lpg=PA73&dq=lavender+%22Toilet+water%22&source=bl&ots=KvUu-BC_pi&sig=x3aGkq6iuuy_A6wWT_A_g1EOuUA&hl=en&ei=fft0TMbIFsT4nAeIgs2aBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CE0Q6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&q=lavender%20%22Toilet%20water%22&f=false Country Wisdom Almanac: 373 Tips, Crafts, Home Improvements, Recipes, and Homemade Remedies]</ref> – a formula called "upper Ten" consists of 1 fluid ounce of oil of lavender, 8 fluid ounces of deodorized alcohol, 3 fluid ounces of [[rose water]], and 80 grains of carbonate of magnesia.<ref name="Keppel154">Keppel, p. 154</ref> * [[Nosegay]] – distilled honey water with cloves, lavender and neroli.<ref>[http://www.perfumeintelligence.co.uk/library/perfume/n/n3/n3p2.htm Nosegay]</ref> * Oriental Toilet Water – an extensive list of ingredients is given in the Useful and Practical Notes section of National Druggist.<ref>The National Druggist, Volume 42, p. 65</ref> * Rose water toilet water – extract of rose 1 pint, of tuberose 1 pint, of cassia 1 pint, of jasmine 4 ounces, tincture of civet 3 ounces. Popular in the Middle East especially Egypt and called 'maward'.<ref>''Beauty—its attainment and preservation'', p. 494</ref> * Viennese Cosmetic Toilet Water – bruised almonds, 15 parts; water of orange flower, 62 parts; water of roses, 62 parts. Rub up the almonds with the waters, allow to stand. Later add borate of soda, 1 part; spirit of benzoin, 2 parts. Dissolve.<ref name="Hopkins875"/> * White Rose Toilet Water – one ounce of triple extract of white rose, 3 drops of oil of rose, 3 drops of oil of rose geranium, 26 ounces of cologne spirits, and 6 ounces of hot water.<ref name="Keppel154"/> * Hugh C. Muldoonin submitted various toilet water formulas he called "Own-make Toilet Specialties" to the ''Bulletin Of Pharmacy'' in 1917.<ref>''Bulletin of pharmacy'', p. 317</ref>
==See also== *[[Eau de Cologne]] *[[Perfume]] *[[Scented water]]
