{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Julia McKenzie
{{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|commas=on|CBE}} | image = Julia McKenzie Head Shot.jpg | caption = Julia McKenzie in 2006 | birthname = Julia Kathleen Nancy McKenzie{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/671144/NY18_Queens_List_-_Final_.pdf|format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]|title=New Year's Honours 2018|work=[[Gov.uk]]|publisher=[[Government Digital Service]]|date=29 December 2017|accessdate=29 December 2017|page=17}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1941|2|17}} | birth_place = [[Enfield Town|Enfield]], [[Middlesex]], England | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Actress, director, presenter, singer | yearsactive = 1966–present | spouse= Jerry Harte (m. 1971; his death 2018){{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/6086837/Julia-McKenzie-on-being-the-new-Miss-Marple-interview.html | title=Julia McKenzie on Being the New Miss Marple: interview | work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | date = 25 August 2009 | accessdate = 27 May 2010 | author = Patay, Ajesh}} }} '''Julia Kathleen Nancy McKenzie''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|commas=on|CBE}} (born 17 February 1941) is an English actress, singer, presenter, and theatre director. On television, she is known for her [[British Academy Television Award for Best Entertainment Performance|BAFTA Award]] nominated role as Hester Fields in the sitcom ''[[Fresh Fields]]'' (1984–86) and its sequel ''[[French Fields]]'' (1989–91), and as [[Miss Marple]] in ''[[Agatha Christie's Marple]]'' (2008–13). McKenzie has also starred in numerous musicals, receiving a 1977 [[Tony Award]] nomination for her work in the [[Broadway (theatre)|Broadway]] [[musical revue|revue]], ''[[Side by Side by Sondheim]]''. A six-time [[Olivier Award]] nominee, she has twice won the [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Actress in a Musical|Olivier Award for Best Actress in a Musical]]; for the 1982 revival of ''[[Guys and Dolls]]'' and the 1993 revival of [[Stephen Sondheim]]'s ''[[Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street]]''. She also starred in the original London productions of the Sondheim musicals ''[[Follies]]'' (1987) and ''[[Into the Woods]]'' (1990). ==Early life== McKenzie was born on 17 February 1941, in [[Municipal Borough of Enfield|Enfield]], [[Middlesex]], England, the daughter of Kathleen Rowe and Albion McKenzie. She attended [[Woodside High School, Wood Green|Tottenham County School]], sometimes known as Tottenham County Grammar School, a co-educational [[grammar school]]. She trained at the [[Guildhall School of Music and Drama]].{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/39/Julia-McKenzie.html|title=Julia McKenzie Biography (1941–)|accessdate=14 March 2014}} ==Career== ===Theatre=== McKenzie's early West End musical credits include ''[[Maggie May (musical)|Maggie May]]'' (1966), ''[[Mame (musical)|Mame]]'' (1969), and ''[[Company (musical)|Company]]'' (1971). She appeared in the West End revue ''[[Side by Side by Sondheim]]'' in 1976, and made her Broadway debut when the show transferred to New York in 1977Hutchins, Michael H. (compiler).[http://www.sondheimguide.com/sideby.html#BP "'Side by Side By Sondheim" Listings"] Sondheimguide.com, accessed 18 August 2011 receiving a [[Tony Award]] nomination for [[Tony Award for Best Featured Actress in a Musical|Best Featured Actress in a Musical]]. She also received a [[Drama Desk Award]] nomination. For her role as Miss Adelaide in the 1982 West End revival of ''[[Guys and Dolls (musical)|Guys and Dolls]]'', she won the first of two [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Actress in a Musical|Olivier Awards for Best Actress in a Musical]].[http://www.olivierawards.com/about/previous-winners/view/item98516/Olivier-Winners-1982/ "Olivier Winners 1982"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130524030543/http://www.olivierawards.com/about/previous-winners/view/item98516/Olivier-Winners-1982/ |date=24 May 2013 }} olivierawards.com, accessed 18 August 2011[http://www.olivierawards.com/about/previous-winners/view/item98528/Olivier-Winners-1994/ "Olivier Winners 1994"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224095916/http://www.olivierawards.com/about/previous-winners/view/item98528/Olivier-Winners-1994/ |date=24 December 2013 }} olivierawards.com, accessed 18 August 2011 For her role in the 1986 West End production of the [[Alan Ayckbourn]] play ''[[Woman in Mind]]'', McKenzie won the [[Evening Standard Theatre Award|Evening Standard Award for Best Actress]]. She went on to appear in the original West End productions of two Sondheim musicals, playing Sally in ''[[Follies]]'' at the [[Shaftesbury Theatre]] in 1987,Hutchins, Michael H. (compiler). [http://www.sondheimguide.com/follies.html#London "'Follies', 1987 London Production"] Sondheimguide.com, accessed 18 August 2011 and the Witch in ''[[Into the Woods]]'' at the Phoenix Theatre in 1990.Hutchins, Michael H. (compiler).[http://www.sondheimguide.com/woods.html#London "'Into the Woods', 1990 London production"] Sondheimguide.com, accessed 18 August 2011 She continued her association with Stephen Sondheim when she starred as Mrs. Lovett in the 1993 London revival of ''[[Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street]]''. The role won her a second Olivier Award in 1994. McKenzie appeared in a [[Royal National Theatre|National Theatre]] 80th birthday tribute to [[Laurence Olivier|Lord Olivier]], ''Happy Birthday, Sir Larry'', on 31 May 1987 in the presence of Olivier himself.Cast list from Happy Birthday, Sir Larry theatre programme, 31 May 1987 ===Television=== On television, McKenzie co-starred with [[Irene Handl]] in the sitcom ''[[Maggie and Her]]'' (1978–79), and with [[Gareth Hunt]] in ''That Beryl Marston...!'' (1981). She went on to greater popularity with British viewers as Hester in the 1980s sitcom ''[[Fresh Fields]]'' opposite [[Anton Rodgers]], and its 1990s sequel ''[[French Fields]]'', for which she was voted [[TV Times]] Favourite Female Comedy Performance for five consecutive years. The role also earned her a 1985 [[BAFTA]] nomination for [[British Academy Television Award for Best Entertainment Performance|Best Entertainment Performance]]. She appeared as Mrs Forthby in ''[[Blott on the Landscape]]'' and as a villager involved in a series of murders in an episode of ''[[Midsomer Murders]]''. Film credits include ''[[Hotel du Lac]]'', ''[[Shirley Valentine]]'', ''[[Bright Young Things]]'' and ''[[These Foolish Things (film)|These Foolish Things]]''. She made several appearances in BBC TV's long running variety show, The Good Old Days. She was the subject of ''[[This Is Your Life (UK TV series)|This Is Your Life]]'' in 1981 when she was surprised by [[Eamonn Andrews]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bigredbook.info/julia_mckenzie.html |title=Julia McKenzie |publisher=Bigredbook.info |date= |accessdate=9 November 2017}} In 2007 she was reunited with Anton Rodgers (again as a husband and wife team) in the [[ITV Network|ITV]] comedy ''You Can Choose Your Friends''. In 2007 she co-starred with [[Michael Gambon]] and [[Judi Dench]] in the BBC1 costume drama series ''[[Cranford (TV series)|Cranford]]'', playing Mrs. Forrester, a military widow of slender means, very attached to her cow Bessie.[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/masterpiece/cranford/characters.html "'Cranford' Characters, Mrs. Forrester"] PBS.com, accessed 18 August 2011 In 2008 she was announced as the replacement for [[Geraldine McEwan]] as ITV's [[Miss Marple]].Hemley, Matthew.[http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/newsstory.php/19793/mckenzie-to-take-on-miss-marple-role-for-itv "McKenzie to take on Miss Marple role for ITV"] ''The Stage'', 11 February 2008 She noted: "It’s difficult because Agatha Christie wrote her in two ways ... First, very much what Geraldine McEwan played: a slight, rather Victorian creature. Then, a little sturdier and tweedier. I chose the latter. A lot of people say they don’t like the tweedier version. But they’re both genuine." Also, she said: "Just about everybody in the world knows about Miss Marple and has an opinion of what she should be like, so I’m under no illusions about the size of the task ahead." McKenzie's first series of Marple comprised ''A Pocket Full of Rye'', ''Murder is Easy'', ''They Do It with Mirrors'' and ''Why Didn't They Ask Evans?''. The second series of the show, which aired in 2010, included ''The Pale Horse,'' ''The Secret of Chimneys,'' ''The Blue Geranium,'' and ''The Mirror Crack'd from Side to Side''. A sixth series, including adaptations of ''A Caribbean Mystery'', ''Greenshaw's Folly'' and ''Endless Night'', began filming in September 2012 and was broadcast in 2013. During the [[2012 Summer Olympics opening ceremony#The Queen's introduction and national anthem|2012 Summer Olympics opening ceremony]] she played [[Elizabeth II|Her Majesty the Queen]] on board the helicopter in the short film ''[[James Bond in film#Happy and Glorious|Happy and Glorious]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2180214/London-Olympics-2012-Gary-Connery-played-Queen-opening-ceremony.html|title='Secret agent' in the coup that made the Queen a global TV comedy star.|date=29 July 2012|work=[[The Mail on Sunday]]|accessdate=29 July 2012|first=Lise|last=Hand}} That year she also played the role of Betty Nicholas in the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] television series ''[[The Town (2012 TV series)|The Town]]''.Wilson, Frances [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/9725377/The-Town-ITV1-review.html The Town, ITV1, review] at ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'', 5 December 2012. Retrieved 16 August 2013 On 26 December 2013, McKenzie appeared as the title character in [[Gangsta Granny (film)|the film adaption]] of [[David Walliams]]' book ''[[Gangsta Granny]]''. In 2015 McKenzie appeared as Shirley Mollison in the BBC mini series ''[[The Casual Vacancy (TV series)|The Casual Vacancy]]''. ===Other work=== She is a radio performer with a long list of credits, including ''[[Blithe Spirit (play)|Blithe Spirit]]'', ''[[The Country Wife]]'' and ''[[A Room with a View]]''. As a director she has staged ''[[Stepping Out (play)|Stepping Out]]'', ''[[Peter Pan]]'', ''[[Hey, Mr. Producer!]]'', ''[[Steel Magnolias]]'', ''[[Putting It Together]]'' and ''[[A Little Night Music]]''. Throughout the early mid 2000s she played A. Oliver in radio adaptations of Agatha Christie novels starring John Moffatt as [[Hercule Poirot]], one such novel was [[Elephants Can Remember]]. She also recorded an audio book of [[Lewis Carroll]]'s ''Through the Looking Glass''.[http://www.silksoundbooks.com/performers/julia-mckenzie/ SilkSoundBooks "About Julia McKenzie"] silksoundbooks.com, accessed 18 August 2011. McKenzie also lent her voice to several animated works for Martin Gates Productions including three films ''[[The Snow Queen (1995 film)|The Snow Queen]]'', ''Jack and the Beanstalk'' and ''[[The Snow Queen's Revenge]]'' and the TV series ''Bimble's Bucket''. In 2018, McKenzie was cast as The Twelve in a [[Big Finish Productions|Big Finish]] production ''The Eighth Doctor - Time War 2''. ==Personal life== In 1971 McKenzie married American actor-director Jerry Harte. He died in 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-5744847/Queen-actress-Julia-McKenzie-returns-Buckingham-Palace-collect-CBE.html|title=Queen actress Julia McKenzie returns to Buckingham Palace to collect CBE|work=[[Daily Mail]]|date=18 May 2018|accessdate=26 May 2018}} McKenzie is a critic of [[fox hunting]] and was among more than 20 high-profile people who signed a letter to Members of Parliament in 2015 to oppose [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] prime minister [[David Cameron]]'s plan to amend the [[Hunting Act 2004]].{{cite news|url=http://news.stv.tv/scotland-decides/news/1324609-snp-to-vote-against-tories-on-fox-hunting-ban-in-england-and-wales/ |title=SNP to vote against Tories on fox hunting ban in England and Wales |work=STV |date=13 July 2015 |accessdate=17 July 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150715203740/http://news.stv.tv/scotland-decides/news/1324609-snp-to-vote-against-tories-on-fox-hunting-ban-in-england-and-wales/ |archivedate=15 July 2015 |df= }} McKenzie was appointed a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] in the [[2018 New Year Honours]] for services to drama.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-42503068|title=In pictures: Entertainment stars recognised in New Year Honours|author=Entertainment & Arts team|work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=29 December 2017|accessdate=30 December 2017}} ==Credits== ===Stage=== ====Acting==== *(London debut) ''[[Maggie May (musical)|Maggie May]]'', Adelphi Theatre, 1966 *Gloria, ''[[Mame (musical)|Mame]]'', Drury Lane Theatre, London, 1969 *Girl in owl coat, ''[[Promises, Promises (musical)|Promises, Promises]]'', Prince of Wales Theatre, London, 1970 *April, ''[[Company (musical)|Company]]'', Her Majesty's Theatre, London, 1971 *''[[Cowardy Custard]]'', Mermaid Theatre, London, 1973 *''Cole'', Mermaid Theatre, 1974''[http://www.sondheimguide.com/porter/colerevue.html Cole]'' 1974 production at sondheimguide.com * ''[[Side by Side by Sondheim]]'', Music Box Theatre, New York City (New York debut), 1977 *''[[The Norman Conquests]]'', 1978 *''[[Alan Ayckbourn#works|Ten Times Table]]'', 1979 *Miriam Dervish, ''[[Outside Edge]]'', Queen's Theatre, 1979 *Lily, ''[[On the Twentieth Century]]'', Her Majesty's Theatre, 1980 *Maggie Hobson, ''[[Hobson's Choice (play)|Hobson's Choice]]'', Lyric Hammersmith Theatre, London, 1981 *Anna Kopecka, ''[[Schweik in the Second World War]]'', Olivier/National Theatre, London, 1982 *Miss Adelaide, ''[[Guys and Dolls]]'', Olivier/National Theatre, 1982 *Susan, ''[[Woman in Mind]]'', Vaudeville Theatre, London, 1986 *Sally Plummer, ''[[Follies]]'', Shaftesbury Theatre, London, then West End Theatre, New York City, 1987 *''Happy Birthday, Sir Larry'', Olivier Theatre, National Theatre, 31 May 1987 *Witch, ''[[Into the Woods]]'', Phoenix Theatre, London, 1990 *Mrs Lovett, ''[[Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street]]'', National Theatre, London, 1993 *''[[Kafka's Dick]]'', Piccadilly Theatre, 1998Dalglish, Darren [http://www.londontheatrearchive.co.uk/archive/secure/archivereviews/kafkasdick98.htm Kafka's Dick, Piccadilly Theatre (Review)] at London Theatre Archive, 26 January 1999 *''[[Fuddy Meers]]'', Arts Theatre, 2004 *''[[The Philadelphia Story (play)|The Philadelphia Story]]'', Old Vic, 2005 ====Directing==== *''[[Stepping Out (play)|Stepping Out]]'', Duke of York's Theatre, London, 1984 *''[[Just So (musical)|Just So]]'', Watermill Theatre, Bagnor, Berkshire, England, 1989 *''[[Steel Magnolias (play)|Steel Magnolias]]'', Lyric Theatre, London, 1989 *''[[Putting It Together]]'', Manhattan Theatre Club Stage I, New York City, 1993 * ''[[Hey, Mr. Producer!]] The Musical World of Cameron Mackintosh'' (stage direction, with Bob Avian), Lyceum Theatre, London, 1998 *''[[A Little Night Music]]'', Tokyo, 1999 ==Filmography== ===Feature films=== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! class = "unsortable" | Notes |- | 1975 | ''[[Dick Deadeye, or Duty Done]]'' | Rose Maybud | |- | 1980 | ''[[The Wildcats of St. Trinian's]]'' | Miss Dolly Dormancott | |- | 1986 | ''[[Hotel du Lac (film)|Hotel du Lac]]'' | | |- | 1989 | ''[[Shirley Valentine (film)|Shirley Valentine]]'' | Gillian | |- |rowspan=2|1996 | ''[[Vol-au-vent (film)|Vol-au-vent]]'' | Audrey | |- | ''[[The Snow Queen's Revenge]]'' | The Snow Queen, Freda and Proprietor | voice |- | 2003 | ''[[Bright Young Things (film)|Bright Young Things]]'' | Lottie Crump | |- |rowspan=2|2006 | ''[[These Foolish Things (film)|These Foolish Things]]'' | Miss Abernethy | |- | ''[[Notes on a Scandal (film)|Notes on a Scandal]]'' | Marjorie | |- | 2013 | ''[[Gangsta Granny (film)|Gangsta Granny]]'' | Granny | |} revision.comment: [[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], replaced: ,o → , o, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: iran → Iran, persian → Persian
revision.text:
{{expand language|topic=|langcode=fa|otherarticle=کَفبیخ|date=December 2017}} [[File:YaldaZibadGonabadKaf.jpg|thumb|Traditional sweet of Yaldā in [[Zibad]], [[Razavi Khorasan Province]]]] [[File:YaldaZibad.jpg|thumb|Yalda Festival Iran]] [[File:YaldaZibadGonabadChela.jpg|thumb|Yalda Festival Iran]] '''KafBikh''' or KafBeex in Persian(کفبیخ)is a kind of traditional sweet in [[Khorasan Province|Khorasan]] in [[Iran]] specially in the city of [[Gonabad]]. In part of Iran there are some special classical traditions specially for the night of [[yalda]]. during this longest night in south Khorasan family are gathering to provide a kind of sweet called Kaf.
==Preparation== The sweet Kaf is based on the root of [[Acanthophyllum squarrosum]] the root should be cleaned and boiled at least three times and the boiled water be discarded until the water has a good smell and good taste.
[[File:Acanthophyllum squarrosum.jpg|thumb|Acanthophyllum squarrosum]]
During this ceremony, the root of the plant called "Chubak", or Bikh which is known as [[Acanthophyllum]] , is soaked in water and after several boils, they are shed in a large pot called "Tegar". Families and men, with a handful of thin pods of pomegranate trees, called the "batches" shake of the liquid, for hours, to become rigid, and this should be done in a cool environment so that the liquid is foamed and then hardened to dry. Like Isfahan Gaz The prepared Kaf is prepared at the end by mixing the juice or sugar, and after being decorated, the walnut and pistachio are taken to the guests. In the meantime, a group of young are allowed to sweeten the kaf by throwing it to each other and rubbing the kaf to face of each other adding happiness to the guests.[http://parssea.org/?p=8399] [[File:KafBeex a kind of sweet in iran.jpg|thumb|KafBeex a kind of sweet in Iran]] Another custom performed in certain parts of Iran and khorasan on the night of [[yalda]] (Chelleh) involves young engaged couples. The men send an edible arrangement containing seven kinds of fruits and a variety of gifts to their fiancees on this night. In some areas, the girl and her family return the favor by sending gifts back for the young man.<ref>{{cite book|title=KafBikh |author=Dr.Mohammad Ajam|publisher=parssea}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Foods in iran |author=http://parssea.org/?p=8399 .|year=2011|publisher=parssea}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Food}} * [[Nowruz]] * [[Gonabad]] * [[zibad]] * [[Jesuite]] * [[Konditorei]] * [[Kuo Yuan Ye Museum of Cake and Pastry]] * [[List of baked goods]] * [[List of desserts]] * [[List of food preparation utensils]] * [[List of pastries]] * [[Mold (cooking implement)]] * [[Pan dulce (sweet bread)]]
==References== {{Reflist}} *Parssea magazine what is Kaf? Gonabadis traditional festivals by Dr Mohammad Ajam Gonapa magazine December 20016[http://parssea.org/?p=8399] -[http://parssea.org/?p=5214] *South Khorasan traditions.Kaf[https://www.mehrnews.com/news/1487975/%DA%A9%D9%81-%D8%B2%D9%86%DB%8C-%D8%A2%D8%A6%DB%8C%D9%86-%D8%B3%D9%86%D8%AA%DB%8C-%D9%85%D8%B1%D8%AF%D9%85-%D8%AE%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%A7%D9%86-%D8%AC%D9%86%D9%88%D8%A8%DB%8C-%D8%AF%D8%B1-%D8%B4%D8%A8-%DA%86%D9%84%D9%87]
==Further reading== * {{cite journal |vauthors=Castro DC, Berridge KC |title=Opioid hedonic hotspot in nucleus accumbens shell: mu, delta, and kappa maps for enhancement of sweetness "liking" and "wanting" |journal=J. Neurosci. |volume=34 |issue=12 |pages=4239–50 |year=2014 |pmid=24647944 |doi=10.1523/JNEUROSCI.4458-13.2014 |pmc=3960467}} * {{cite journal |vauthors=Peciña S, Berridge KC |title=Hedonic hot spot in nucleus accumbens shell: where do mu-opioids cause increased hedonic impact of sweetness? |journal=J. Neurosci. |volume=25 |issue=50 |pages=11777–86 |year=2005 |pmid=16354936 |doi=10.1523/JNEUROSCI.2329-05.2005 |url=}}
{{refend}} {{Taste}}
[[Category:Articles with inconsistent citation formats]] [[Category:Gustation]] [[Category:Festivals in Iran]] [[Category:Persian culture]]

[[File:The Rhetoricians, circa 1655, by Jan Steen (1625-1679) - IMG 7324.JPG|thumb|The Rhetoricians, circa 1655, by [[Jan Steen]]. The painting depicts a rederijker reading his poem, while hanging over the balcony the [[blason]] of his chamber of rhetoric can be seen; in this case the Amsterdam society "[[Egelantier]]", whose symbol was a wild rose (egelantier) and whose motto was "In Liefde Bloeiend".]] [[File:Rhetoric-enthroned-invitation-antwerp-landjuweel-1561.jpg|thumb|Printed invitation to other chambers of rhetoric by the Antwerp ''[[Violieren]]'', for a ''landjuweel'' event, lasting 19 days, in 1561]] A '''[[chamber of rhetoric]]''' was a civic society for the promotion of poetry, drama and eloquence. They also maintained literary contact between different towns, partly through competitions in which chambers from other places were invited to compete, producing a shared literary culture across different jurisdictions. Growing from medieval confraternities that performed mystery plays and miracle plays for feast days and civic festivals, they were widespread in the [[Low Countries]] during the [[Renaissance literature|Renaissance]] period, with some survivals and revivals in subsequent periods down to the present day. They were often named after flowers or patron saints.
The following list, arranged by the town, city, liberty or lordship in which a chamber was active, is incomplete.

/* Discovery */Fixing [[Wikipedia:Disambiguation pages with links|links to disambiguation pages]], replaced: [[diving| → [[Underwater diving|
revision.text:
The '''Lough Lene Boat''', also known as '''The Monks' Boat''', is an [[Underwater archaeology|underwater archaeological]] artifact from [[prehistoric Ireland]]. It was discovered in 1968 on the east side of [[Lough Lene]], [[County Westmeath]] nearest to the Cummerstown/Windtown townlands of [[Collinstown]]. [[Radiocarbon dating]] revealed that the boat was constructed sometime between the [[Early history of Ireland|1st and 4th century]].[http://www.askaboutireland.ie/reading-room/environment-geography/physical-landscape/lakelands-of-westmeath/lough-lene/the-monks-boat/ The Monk's boat], Ask About Ireland. Retrieved 15 May 2011. == Discovery == [[File:NunsTurgesius Castle isles Lough Lene.JPG|thumb|right|[[Nuns Island]], a site popularly associated with the history of the Lough Lene Boat, is visible in this photo of [[Lough Lene]] shows. Turgesius Island and the Castle Isles are also visible. The mainland is in the foreground.]] The boat, which resembled a "dug out [[canoe]]", was discovered by [[Underwater diving|divers]] belonging to the local [[Mullingar]] Sub Aqua Club. The divers moved the boat into shallower water and then, on 28 September 1958, brought it ashore for examination by [[Archaeology|experts]].[http://www.askaboutireland.ie/image_large?asset_id=7657 Photo of the Mullingar Sub Aqua Club] == Characteristics == P. O hEailidhe from the [[National Museum of Ireland]] reported:
"the Lough Lene boat combines techniques of [[sewn boat]] construction together with that of [[Mortise and tenon|mortise-and-tenon]] in a way which cannot be paralleled elsewhere at present." [http://www.askaboutireland.ie/show_narrative_page.do?page_id=4070 P. O hEailidhe, National Museum of Ireland] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927220237/http://www.askaboutireland.ie/show_narrative_page.do?page_id=4070 |date=2007-09-27 }}
==Legend== "The Monks' Boat" appellation comes from a [[History of the Republic of Ireland|20th century]] [[folklore|local tradition]] that associates the boat with the [[monk]]s of the [[Ruins|ruined]] [[Fore Abbey]]. Although the boat pre-dates the [[abbey]] by several centuries, it is thought that the boat may have been sunk while moving religious artifacts used during [[Mass (liturgy)|mass]] in the Fore Abbey and on the [[convent]] on [[Nuns Island, Lough Lene|Nuns Island]]. Another [[legend]] holds that locals, believing the boat [[curse]]d with bad fortune, did not wish the boat recovered. Because of theories about a possible [[Roman Britain|Romano-British]] origin for the Lough Lene Boat, some have even speculated a connection between the vessel and [[St. Patrick]]. According to the [[Annals of Ulster]] (a [[Early Modern Ireland 1536–1691|late medieval]] document in which dates, especially of earlier events, are suspect) the [[Early Medieval Ireland 800–1166|era of St. Patrick's life]] coincides with scientific estimation of when the boat was constructed. ==The Lough Lene Bell== [[Image:Lough Lene Bell Riplica.JPG|thumb|right|400px|Lough Lene Bell]] In 1882, the Royal Irish Academy was presented with the Bell of [[Lough Lene]] by the Barbavila estate proprietor, Mr. William Barlow Smythe. The bell had been discovered the previous year in Lough Lene by a boy fishing for eels on Castle Island, which was owned by Smythe at the time. Given the close proximity to the [[Fore Abbey]], the estate owner Smythe concluded that the bell possibly belonged to the St Feichin Abbey; During the Viking and Anglo-Norman oppressions, it may have been transferred to Nun's Island, before being eventually being hidden upon Castle Island. The [[Bell (instrument)|Bell]] has a faint outline of the Christian [[Celtic cross]] upon opposing sides of the bell and an ornamental periphiral border. Smythe pronounced that ornamentation was generally reserved for the cases or [[shrine]]s for that era and was therefore most unusual. The bell appears similar to two other bells from that early Christian period. These had been found in [[Bangor, County Down]] in the year 1832, and another in [[Cashel, County Tipperary]] in 1849. Smythe, the Barbavila owner, believed that the Lough Lene Bell was contemporary to these bells which were believed to be from the 7th century, therefore supporting his theory that it was possible that it could have been a relic of [[St. Feichin]]s. The Folklore Commission also hold an account of Kit "the Blade" Fagan's discovery of the bell, which consequentially triggered a local treasure hunt for further artifacts around [[Collinstown]] and Fore. While the original ''Lough Lene Bell'' remains within the National Museum, a half sized replica holds a place of pride as the [[Ceann Comhairle]]'s Bell in Dáil Éireann. This replica was presented to the Dáil in 1931 by the widow of Major [[Bryan Cooper (politician)|Bryan Cooper]], a former member of the House.[http://www.askaboutireland.ie/reading-room/environment-geography/physical-landscape/lakelands-of-westmeath/lough-lene/the-bell-of-lough-lene/index.xml The bell of Lough Lene], Ask About Ireland. Retrieved 15 May 2011. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.askaboutireland.ie/image_large?asset_id=7657 The Lough Lene Boat] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070927220237/http://www.askaboutireland.ie/show_narrative_page.do?page_id=4070 Lough Lene Monks Boat text] * [http://www.osi.ie Ordnance Survey Maps of Ireland] (OSI) no 41 and no. 42 * [[:fr:Saint Patrick|Saint Patrick (in French)]] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070930015145/http://www.askaboutireland.ie/show_narrative_page.do?page_id=3914 Bell of Lough Lene] * [http://www.westmeathcoco.ie Westmeath County Council] * [http://www.oireachtas.ie/viewdoc.asp?fn=/documents/tour/kildare06.asp Lough Lene Bell] [[Category:Celtic art]] [[Category:County Westmeath]]

{{Infobox character | colour = #fc9 | colour text = | name = Malcolm Reynolds | series = [[Firefly (TV series)|Firefly]] | image = [[Image:MalReynoldsFirefly.JPG|250px|Malcolm Reynolds]] | caption = [[Nathan Fillion]] as Malcolm Reynolds | first = "[[Serenity (Firefly episode)|Serenity]]" ([[Firefly (TV series)|''Firefly'']] episode) | last = | creator = [[Joss Whedon]] | portrayer = [[Nathan Fillion]] | nickname = Mal, Captain, Captain Tight Pants (Kaylee) | alias = | gender = Male | occupation = Captain of ''[[Serenity (Firefly vessel)|Serenity]]'' | title = | family = | spouse = [[List of characters in the Firefly universe#Saffron|"Saffron"]] | children = | relatives = Unnamed mother | nationality = | lbl21 = Homeworld | data21 = [[List of Firefly planets and moons#Additional planets|Shadow]] }} '''Malcolm''' "'''Mal'''" '''Reynolds''' is a [[fictional character]] and the [[protagonist]] of the [[Firefly (franchise)|''Firefly'' franchise]]. Mal is played by actor [[Nathan Fillion]] in the 2002 [[TV series]] [[Firefly (TV series)|''Firefly'']] and the 2005 film ''[[Serenity (2005 film)|Serenity]]''. In the series, Mal is a former [[Browncoat]] [[sergeant]] and the captain of the [[Serenity (Firefly vessel)|"''Firefly''-class" spaceship ''Serenity'']]. The character was named #18 in ''[[TV Guide]]''{{'s}} Greatest Sci-Fi Legends list in 2004.<ref name="legend">{{cite web |url=http://whedonesque.com/comments/4511 |title=Captain Mal Reynolds features in '25 Greatest Sci-fi legends' list |website=Whedonesque.com |date=July 27, 2004 |author=Simon |accessdate=July 16, 2006}}</ref>
==Production details== Conceived by [[Joss Whedon]], the character Malcolm Reynolds was the only definite character he had in mind when formulating the ensemble cast. He wanted a hero, but not a hero in the classic sense; someone that is "everything that a hero is not."<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2010/03/the-10-greatest-anti-heroes-5-malcolm-reynolds.html |title=The 10 Greatest Anti-Heroes: #5 Malcolm Reynolds |magazine=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]] |date=March 17, 2010 |accessdate=October 12, 2013}}</ref>
In the proposed pilot, Mal was much darker and considerably more closed-off. Fox network executives objected, and asked that Mal be "lightened up". For the second episode ("[[The Train Job]]"), Whedon created a more "jolly" Mal Reynolds.<ref>Whedon, ''Train Job: Director's Commentary,'' Track 1</ref>
Fillion shares his view on the motivations of the character he portrayed. Mal has lost so much that each character in the crew he has gathered on ''Serenity'' represents an aspect of himself he no longer has. "In Wash, he has a lust for life and a sense of humor he's lost. In Jayne, he has selfishness. In Book, he has spirituality. In Kaylee, he has innocence. Everybody represents a facet of himself that he has lost and that's why he keeps them close and safe, and yet at arm's length."<ref name="FFC26"/>
===Casting=== The role was originally written for ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]'' co-star [[Nicholas Brendon]] (who played [[Xander Harris]]);<ref>Q&A with Nicholas Brendan — Supanova Convention in Sydney, Australia - 13 October 2007, also Q&A with Nicholas Brendan - Armageddon Expo in Melbourne, Australia - 23 October 2011.</ref>{{better source|date=April 2018}} however, the shooting schedule conflicted with his commitment to ''Buffy''.
Whedon approached Nathan Fillion to play the lead, and after explaining the premise and showing Fillion the treatment for the pilot, Fillion was eager for the role.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.whedon.info/article.php3?id_article=1531&img= |title=Interview with Nathan Fillion — Dreamwatch Magazine 107 |website=Whedon.info |date=September 9, 2003 |accessdate=July 11, 2006}}</ref> Fillion was called back several times to read for the part before he was cast. He noted that "It was really thrilling. It was my first lead and I was pretty nervous, but I really wanted that part and I wanted to tell those stories."<ref name="FFC26">Whedon, ''Firefly Companion, Vol 1'', p.26.</ref>
===Costume design=== Los Angeles prop shop Applied Effects was approached by Randy Erikson to create Mal's main gun, a "Moses Brothers Self-Defense Engine Frontier Model B",<ref name="scifi">{{Cite web |url=http://www.scifi.com/sfw/cool/sfw17440.html |title=Official Malcolm Reynolds Stunt Pistol |first=Sean |last=Huxter |website=[[Scifi.com]] |date=October 15, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071130182729/http://www.scifi.com/sfw/cool/sfw17440.html |archivedate=November 30, 2007}}</ref> and gave them a week and a half. Erikson provided a foamcore conceptual mockup and the base guns, one of which was a five-shot .38 [[caliber]] [[Taurus Model 85]] revolver. Erikson researched [[American Civil War]]-era revolvers for inspiration and the final mockup had a brass or bronze look, with the revolver a little elongated. The biggest challenge was masking the shape of the original revolver and still keeping it operable.<ref>Whedon, ''Firefly Companion, Vol 1'', pp.79-80.</ref>
On the TV series ''Firefly'', a cast [[bronze]] pistol was used, but for the film ''Serenity'', a more detailed replica was created which had moving [[firearm action|action]] and a [[Blank (cartridge)#Applications|blank pistol]] hidden inside, so that it could be fired in [[close-up]]s. Since this version was quite heavy, a [[resin]] replica was also constructed, which in addition to being less tiring for the actors to carry, could be thrown or dropped with less fear of injury.<ref name="quant">{{Cite web |url=http://www.quantummechanix.com/IN%20THE%20WORKS/4C9CB708-01B9-4E9F-A5F7-3FCE0DED9598.html |title=The Metal Mal Hero Pistol Replica |website=Quantummechanix.com |date=September 30, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071210062342/http://www.quantummechanix.com/IN%20THE%20WORKS/4C9CB708-01B9-4E9F-A5F7-3FCE0DED9598.html |archivedate=December 10, 2007}}</ref> Nonfunctional replicas of the gun are commercially available for [[fan (person)|fans]] and [[Collecting|collectors]].<ref name="scifi"/><ref name="quant"/>
GBB Custom Gunleather was tasked with creating Mal's gun holster, which was made out of oak-tanned carving leather.<ref>Whedon, ''Firefly Companion, Vol 1'', p.81.</ref> The character's coat, a relic of his time as a [[Browncoat]], was a collaboration between Firefly costume designer [[Shawna Trpcic]] and Jonathan A. Logan, a leather artist. Trpcic sketched her idea and a cloth mockup was created before the final was made with domestic-farmed deerskin. The cuffs are actually the sleeves folded back, evoking the style of Oriental robes with their silk linings. Two coats were made for the character, one called "Number 1" coat and another called "The Hero" coat. The Number 1 coat's bullet hole is drawn in, while The Hero version has a detailed cut and sewn repair.<ref>Whedon, ''Firefly Companion, Vol 1'', p.83.</ref> As with the gun, replicas of Malcolm Reynolds' coat have also been made available commercially for fans.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://abbyshot.blogspot.com/2009/11/browncoat-launched-aim-to-misbehave.html |title=The Malcolm Reynolds Browncoat Replica |website=AbbyShot Blog |date=November 2, 2009}}</ref>
==Character biography== Malcolm's main mission is to keep his crew alive and to keep his ship flying. As ''Firefly'' writer Tim Minear stated in an interview: "It's just about getting by. That's always been the mission statement of what the show is — getting by."<ref>{{cite web |url = http://tv.zap2it.com/tveditorial/tve_main/1,1002,271%7c78704%7c1%7c,00.html |title = Fox's 'Firefly' Keeps the Lights On |website = Zap2it.com |first = Kate |last = O'Hare |date = October 31, 2002 |accessdate = July 4, 2006 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070526111034/http://tv.zap2it.com/tveditorial/tve_main/1,1002,271%7C78704%7C1%7C,00.html |archivedate = May 26, 2007 |df = }}</ref> In ''Serenity'', Mal says of himself: "[If the] Wind blows Northerly, I go North."<ref name="Whedon, Serenity, DVD">Whedon, ''Serenity'', DVD.</ref>
Mal was raised by his mother and "about 40 hands" on a ranch on the planet Shadow.<ref>Whedon, ''Firefly: the complete series: "Our Mrs. Reynolds"''</ref> Though Mal usually seems more practical than intellectual, he occasionally surprises his friends by displaying familiarity with disparate literature varying from the works of [[Xiang Yu]]<ref>Whedon, ''Firefly: the complete series: "War Stories"''</ref> to [[The Rime of the Ancient Mariner|poems]]<ref name="Whedon, Serenity, DVD"/> by [[Samuel Taylor Coleridge]], though he has no idea "who" [[Mona Lisa]] is.
Mal volunteered for the [[Browncoat|Independents]] army during the Unification War against the [[Alliance (Firefly)|Alliance]], gaining the rank of sergeant during that time. His loyal second-in-command [[Zoe Washburne|Zoe]] was by his side for most of the war, surviving many dangerous conflicts with him. The show mentions three such battles, including the Battle of Du-Khang in 2510 (featured in "[[The Message (Firefly)|The Message]]") and a long winter campaign in New Kashmir (as told by Zoe in "[[War Stories (Firefly episode)|War Stories]]") where he commanded a platoon. Mal was also involved in the ground campaign during the Battle of Sturges (as seen in the comic book ''[[Serenity: Those Left Behind]]''), which according to [[List of minor characters in Firefly#Badger|Badger]] was the "bloodiest and shortest battle in all the war", although Mal considers it a distant second. Mal fought in many more battles, but the turning point for him and the Independents came with their physical and emotional defeat at the ''Battle of Serenity Valley'' on the planet [[List of Firefly planets and moons#Hera|Hera]]. On-screen information in ''Serenity'' shows him to have been attached to the 57th Overlanders Brigade; in the series pilot, Badger calls it the "Balls and Bayonets Brigade", though it is unclear whether this was a disparaging nickname coined by Badger himself or the actual unit [[sobriquet]] (A deleted scene in ''Serenity'' marks it as the actual unit nickname. It is unknown if the deleted scene can be considered canon or not.)
After the war, Mal acquired his own ship, a derelict 03-K64 ''Firefly''-class transport. Mal named the ship ''Serenity'' after the Battle of Serenity Valley, the decisive battle of the Unification War.
==Reception== Fillion won the "Cinescape Genre Face of the Future Award — Male" award by the Academy of Science Fiction, Fantasy & Horror Films, USA for his role as Malcolm Reynolds. Fillion also won the [[SyFy Genre Awards]] in 2006 for ''Best Actor/Television'' and was runner-up for ''Best Actor/Movie''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://syfyportal.com/news.php?id=2895 |title=SyfyPortal Awards |accessdate=October 8, 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061107100529/http://www.syfyportal.com/news.php?id=2895 |archivedate=November 7, 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
The character was named #18 in ''[[TV Guide]]''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s "Greatest Sci-fi legends" list in 2004.<ref name="legend" /> In 2008, ''[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]'' ranked Mal as #34 on their list of the 100 Greatest Movie Characters.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.empireonline.com/100-greatest-movie-characters/default.asp?c=51 |title=The 100 Greatest Movie Characters |magazine=Empire |accessdate=June 11, 2009}}</ref> In 2011, ''[[SFX (magazine)|SFX Magazine]]'' voted Mal Reynolds #1 on their Top 100 Sci-Fi icons of the century.
In her review of the film ''Serenity'' for ''[[The New York Times]]'', [[Manohla Dargis]] had this to say about the character and Nathan Fillion: "Mal is no [[Neo (The Matrix)|Neo]] redux; he's closer to [[Indiana Jones]], if absent [[Harrison Ford]]'s rakishly handsome looks and star magnetism. Like the rest of the cast, Mr. Fillion is a charming performer, but he borrows rather than owns the screen, which dovetails with Mr. Whedon's modest aspirations for this film."<ref>{{cite news |last=Dargis |first=Manohla |date=September 30, 2005 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/09/30/movies/scruffy-space-cowboys-fighting-their-failings.html |title=Scruffy Space Cowboys Fighting Their Failings |newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref>

revision.comment: Provided citation for the number of mastaba tombs on the Giza Plateau.
revision.text:
[[File:Mastaba-faraoun-3.jpg|right|thumb|Example of a mastaba]] A '''mastaba''' ({{IPAc-en|'|m|æ|s|t|ə|b|ə}},<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/mastaba?showCookiePolicy=true|title=Mastaba: definition|publisher=Collins Dictionary|access-date=23 October 2014|date=n.d.}}</ref> {{IPAc-en|'|m|ɑː|s|t|ɑː|b|ɑː|}} or {{IPAc-en|m|ɑː|'|s|t|ɑː|b|ɑː|}}) or '''[[Pr (hieroglyph)|pr]]-[[Djed|djt]]''' (meaning "house for eternity" or "eternal house" in [[Egyptian language|Ancient Egyptian]]) is a type of [[ancient Egyptian tomb]] in the form of a flat-roofed, rectangular structure with inward sloping sides, constructed out of mud-bricks (from the Nile River). These edifices marked the burial sites of many eminent Egyptians during Egypt's [[Early Dynastic Period (Egypt)|Early Dynastic Period]] and [[Old Kingdom of Egypt|Old Kingdom]]. In the Old Kingdom epoch, local kings began to be buried in [[Egyptian pyramids|pyramids]] instead of in mastabas, although non-royal use of mastabas continued for over a thousand years. Egyptologists call these tombs ''mastaba'', from the Arabic word {{lang|ar|مسطبة}} "stone bench".<ref name="Bench">{{cite web|title=Mastaba Tomb of Perneb|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/543937|website=Met Museum|access-date=22 October 2016}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Piece of waste limestone. Accounts, in black ink, by workmen of the number of stone blocks delivered for the Meidum Pyramid. 4th Dynasty. From Pyramid waste, mastaba 17 at Meidum, Egypt. The Petrie Museum of Egyptian Archaeology, London.jpg|thumb|Piece of waste limestone. Accounts, in black ink, by workmen of the number of stone blocks delivered for the Meidum Pyramid. 4th Dynasty. From Pyramid waste, mastaba 17 at Meidum, Egypt. The Petrie Museum of Egyptian Archaeology, London]] The [[afterlife]] became a main focus of Egyptian civilization and ruled every aspect of the society.{{citation needed|date= March 2016}} This is reflected in Egyptian architecture and most prominently by the enormous amounts of time, money, and manpower involved in the building of tombs.<ref name="Hamlin">{{cite book |last= Hamlin |first= Talbot |title= Architecture through the Ages |location= New York |publisher= Putnam |year= 1954 |page= 30 }}</ref> Ancient Egyptians believed the soul could live only if the body was preserved from corruption and depredation as well as fed.<ref>{{cite book |last= Badawy |first= Alexander |title= Architecture in Ancient Egypt and the Near East |location= Cambridge |publisher= MIT Press |year= 1966 |page= 46 }}</ref>
Starting in the [[Prehistoric Egypt|Predynastic]] era and continuing into the later dynasties, the ancient Egyptians developed increasingly complex and effective methods for preserving and protecting the bodies of the dead. The ancient Egyptians initially buried their dead in pit graves dug out from the sand. The body of the deceased was buried inside the pit on a mat, usually along with some items believed to help them in the afterlife. The first tomb structure that the Egyptians built was the mastaba. Mastabas provided better protection from scavenging animals and from grave robbers. However, the human remains were not in contact with the dry desert sand, so natural mummification could not take place. Use of the more secure mastabas required Ancient Egyptians to devise a system of artificial mummification.<ref>{{cite book |title= Ancient Egypt and the Near East |location= Cambridge |publisher= MIT Press |year= 1966 |page= 7 }}</ref> Until at least the Old Period or First Intermediate Period, only high officials and royalty would be buried in these mastabas.<ref> {{cite web |last= BBC|title= mastabas |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/ancient/egyptians/pyramid_gallery_02.shtml |publisher= BBC|accessdate= 29 May 2013 }} </ref>
==Structure== [[File:Mastaba schematics.svg|right|thumb|Structure of a mastaba]] The word 'mastaba' comes from the [[Arabic]] word for a bench of mud,<ref>{{cite book |authorlink=Alan Gardiner |last=Gardiner |first=A. |year=1964 |title=Egypt of the Pharahos |page=57 n7 |location=New York |publisher=Oxford University Press }}</ref> and when seen from a distance a mastaba does resemble a bench. Historians speculate that the Egyptians may have borrowed architectural ideas from Mesopotamia since at the time they were both building similar structures.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gascone|first=Bamber|title=History of architecture|url=http://www.historyworld.net/wrldhis/PlainTextHistories.asp?ParagraphID=arb|publisher=History of the world|accessdate=29 May 2013}}</ref>
The above-ground structure of a mastaba is rectangular in shape with inward-sloping sides and a flat roof. The exterior building materials were initially bricks made of sun dried mud, which was readily available from the Nile River. Even after more durable materials like stone came into use, all but the most important monumental structures were built from the easily available mud bricks.<ref>{{cite journal |last=R. |first=C. L. |title=A Model of the Mastaba-Tomb of Userkaf-Ankh |journal=Metropolitan Museum of Art Bulletin |volume=8 |year=1913 |issue=6 |pages=125–130 |jstor=3252928 }}</ref> Mastabas were often about four times as long as they were wide, and many rose to at least 30 feet in height. The mastaba was built with a north-south orientation, which the Ancient Egyptians believed was essential for access to the afterlife. This above-ground structure had space for a small offering chapel equipped with a false door. Priests and family members brought food and other offerings for the soul, or ''[[Ba (Egyptian soul)|ba]]'', of the deceased because Egyptians believed that the soul had to be maintained in order to continue to exist in the afterlife.
Inside the mastaba, a deep chamber was dug into the ground and lined with stone and bricks. The burial chambers were cut deep, until they passed the bedrock, and were lined with wood.<ref>{{cite web|last=BBC|title=Mastabas|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/ancient/egyptians/pyramid_gallery_02.shtml|publisher=bbc|accessdate=29 May 2013}}</ref> A second hidden chamber called a "serdab" (سرداب), from the Persian word for "cellar",<ref>{{cite book | last = Bard | first = K. A. | title = Encyclopedia of the Archaeology of Ancient Egypt | publisher = Routledge | location = New York | year = 1999 |isbn=978-0415185899}}</ref> was used to store anything that may have been considered essential for the comfort of the deceased in the afterlife, such as beer, cereal, grain, clothes, and precious items.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lewis|first=Ralph|title=Burial practices, and Mummies|url=http://www.egyptianmuseum.org/burialpracticesgallery|publisher=Rosicrucian Museum|accessdate=29 May 2013}}</ref> The mastaba housed a statue of the deceased that was hidden within the masonry for its protection. High up the walls of the serdab were small openings that would allow the ''ba'' to leave and return to the body (represented by the statue); Ancient Egyptians believed the ''ba'' had to return to its body or it would die. These openings "were not meant for viewing the statue but rather for allowing the fragrance of burning incense, and possibly the spells spoken in rituals, to reach the statue".<ref>{{cite book |last=Arnold |first=Dorothea |title=When the Pyramids were Built: Egyptian Art of the Old Kingdom |location=New York |publisher=Metropolitan Museum of Art |year=1999 |page=12 |isbn=978-0870999086 }}</ref>
==Architectural evolution== [[File:Giza pyramid complex (map).svg|right|thumb|Map of the [[Giza Plateau]], showing the mastabas constructed within the complex]] The mastaba was the standard type of tomb in pre-dynastic and early dynastic Egypt for both the [[pharaoh]] and the social elite. The ancient city of [[Abydos, Egypt|Abydos]] was the location chosen for many of the [[cenotaph]]s. The royal cemetery was at [[Saqqara]], overlooking the capital of early times, [[memphis, Egypt|Memphis]].<ref name="Fletcher">{{cite book |last=Fletcher |first=Banister |year=1996 |title=A History of Architecture |edition=20th |location=Oxford |publisher=Butterworth-Heinemann |isbn=978-0750622677 }}</ref>
Mastabas evolved over the early dynastic period. During the [[1st Dynasty]], a mastaba was constructed simulating house plans of several rooms, a central one containing the sarcophagus and others surrounding it to receive the abundant funerary offerings. The whole was built in a shallow pit above which a brick superstructure covering a broad area. The typical [[2nd Dynasty|2nd]] and [[3rd Dynasty]] mastabas was the 'stairway mastaba', the tomb chamber of which sank deeper than before and was connected to the top with an inclined shaft and stairs.<ref name="Fletcher"/>
Even after pharaohs began to construct pyramids for their tombs in the 3rd Dynasty, members of the nobility continued to be buried in mastaba tombs. This is especially evident on the [[Giza Plateau]], where at least 150 mastaba tombs have been constructed alongside the pyramids.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Davis|first=Ben|date=1997|title=THE FUTURE OF THE PAST|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/24995879|journal=Scientific American|volume=277|issue=2|pages=89–92}}</ref>
In the [[4th Dynasty]] (c. 2613 to 2494 BC), [[rock-cut tombs]] began to appear. These were tombs built into the rock cliffs in [[Upper Egypt]] in an attempt to further thwart grave robbers.<ref>{{cite journal |last=R. |first=L. E. |title=Two Mastaba Chambers |journal=Museum of Fine Arts Bulletin |volume=8 |issue=45 |year=1910 |pages=19–20 |jstor=4423469 }}</ref> Mastabas, then, were developed with the addition of offering chapels and vertical shafts. [[5th Dynasty]] mastabas had elaborate chapels consisting of several rooms, columned halls and '[[serdab]]'. The actual tomb chamber was built below the south-end of mastaba, connected by a slanting passage to a stairway emerging in the center of a columned hall or court.
Mastabas are still well attested in the Middle Kingdom. Here they had a revival. They were often solid structures with the decoration only on the outside.<ref>Arnold, D. (2008): ''Middle Kingdom Tomb Architecture at Lisht'', Egyptian Expedition XXVIII, Metropolitan Museum of Art: New York {{ISBN|9781588391940}}, S. 26-30</ref>
By the time of the [[New Kingdom]] (which began with the [[18th Dynasty]] around 1550 BC), "the mastaba becomes rare, being largely superseded by the independent pyramid chapel above a burial chamber".<ref>{{cite book |last=Badawy |first=Alexander |title=Architecture in Ancient Egypt and the Near East |location=Cambridge |publisher=MIT Press |year=1966 |page=51 }}</ref>
==References== {{Commons category|Mastabas}} {{Reflist}}

The '''Militant League for German Culture''' (German: ''Kampfbund für deutsche Kultur'', ''KfdK''), was a nationalistic anti-Semitic political society during the [[Weimar Republic]] and the [[Nazi]] era. It was founded in 1928 as the ''Nationalsozialistische Gesellschaft für deutsche Kultur'' (NGDK, National Socialist Society for German Culture') by Nazi ideologue [[Alfred Rosenberg]] and remained under his leadership until it was reorganized and renamed to the National Socialist Culture Community (''Nationalsozialistische Kulturgemeinde'') in 1934. Its aim was to make a significant imprint on cultural life in Germany that was based on the aims and objectives of the inner circles of the Nazi Party. Upon its reorganization, it was merged with the ''Deutsche Bühne'' (German Stage), connected with the establishment of the official body for cultural surveillance, the "Dienstelle Rosenberg" (DRbg) and was later known as the [[Amt Rosenberg]].
==Members and followers== The number of members, who were organized in local chapters, rose from approximately 300 in 25 chapters in April 1929 to about 38,000 in 450 chapters by October 1933.
The members and supporters included representatives of the extreme right wing of the National Socialist movement. These included anti-Semitic literary historians [[Adolf Bartels]], Ludwig Polland, [[Gustaf Kossinna]], physicist and [[Einstein]]-opponent [[Philipp Lenard]], publishers [[Hugo Bruckmann]] and [[Julius Friedrich Lehmann]], the leaders of the Bayreuth Society [[Winifred Wagner]], Daniela Thode, [[Hans Freiherr von Wolzogen]], the widow of racial ideologist [[Houston Stewart Chamberlain]], Eva Chamberlain, the composer [[Paul Graener]], the philosophers [[Otto Friedrich Bollnow]],<ref>[http://www.kant.uni-mainz.de/ks/history/leaman.html Die Kant-Studien im Dritten Reich], George Leaman, Bowling Green / Gerd Simon, Tübingen</ref> and [[Eugen Herrigel]],<ref>Die Nazifizierung der Philosophie an der Universität Breslau 1933-1945, von Norbert Kapferer, LIT Verlag, 2002, {{ISBN|3825854515}}</ref> the poet and later president of the ''Reichsschrifttumskammer'' [[Hanns Johst]]; the architect Paul Schulze-Naumburg, who edited the periodical ''Kunst und Rasse'' [''Art and Race''], and who spoke at many events; Gustav Havemann, a violinist and later leader of the Reichsmusikkammer (who founded and lead a Kampfbund orchestra); the theater director Karl von Schirach; Fritz Kloppe who led ''[[Werwolf]]'', a paramilitary organization; and the theologian and nationalist musicologist [[Fritz Stein]]. [[Othmar Spann]], Austrian political philosopher and a teacher of [[Friedrich Hayek]]. After an ad on April 20, 1933, Edwin Werner, PhD, founded his own association in Passau.<ref>Anna Rosmus: Hitlers Nibelungen, Samples Grafenau 2015, pp. 61f</ref>
Corporate and organizational members included the Association of German Fraternities [Deutsche Burschenschaften], the German Homeland Association [Deutsche Landsmannschaft], German College Gymnastics Associations [Turnerschaften an deutschen Hochschulen], the Association of German Guilds [Deutsche Gildenschaften], the Association of German Glee Clubs [Deutsche Sängerschaft], the German College Music Society [Sondershäuser Verband], and German College Art Society [Deutscher Hochschulring].
==Publications and political action == [[File:Nuremberg Trials defendant Wilhelm Frick in his cell 1945.jpeg|thumb|Frick in his cell, November 1945]] The Society published the periodical ''Mitteilung des Kampfbundes für deutsche Kultur'' [''Proceedings of the KfdK''] from 1929 to 1931. Under the heading "Signs of the Times" they listed their enemies: [[Erich Kästner]], [[Kurt Tucholsky]], [[Thomas Mann]], [[Bertolt Brecht]], [[Walter Mehring]], and the Berlin Institute for Sexual Research. Later the most frequently mentioned were [[Paul Klee]], [[Wassily Kandinsky|Kandinsky]], [[Kurt Schwitters]], the [[Bauhaus|Bauhaus Movement]], [[Emil Nolde]], Karl Hofter, [[Max Beckmann]], and [[Georg Grosz]]. Books by [[Ernst Toller]], [[Arnold Zweig]], [[Jakob Wassermann]], [[Lion Feuchtwanger]], [[Arnolt Bronnen]], [[Leonhard Frank]], [[Emil Ludwig]], and [[Alfred Neumann (writer)|Alfred Neumann]] were dismissed as not properly German. In 1930, the society directed a campaign against [[Ernst Barlach]] and the so-called "hate art" (''Hetzkunst'') of [[Käthe Kollwitz]].
The Society published ''German Culture Watch: Journal of the KfdK'' in October 1932, reprinted in 1933, under the editorship of [[Hans Hinkel]].
Their activities had a nationwide impact. In 1930 [[Wilhelm Frick]], the Nazi Interior and Cultural minister of Thuringia and KdfK regional leader, named [[Hans Severus Ziegler]] of the Schultze-Naumburg firm as director of the Weimar Architecture Institute. He immediately dismissed all practitioners of the Bauhaus style. Frick ordered artworks by "[[degenerate art]]ists" to be removed from the [[Schlossmuseum, Weimar|Schlossmuseum in Weimar]]. These included works by [[Otto Dix]], [[Lyonel Feininger]], [[Wassily Kandinsky|Kandinsky]], [[Paul Klee]], Barlack, [[Oskar Kokoschka]], [[Franz Marc]], and [[Emil Nolde]], although the latter was himself a nazi. Works by modernist composers [[Stravinsky]] and [[Hindemith]] were struck from state-subsidized concert programs, and books by [[Erich Maria Remarque]], and films by [[Sergei Eisenstein|Eisenstein]], [[Pudovkin]], and [[Georg Wilhelm Pabst]] were banned outright.
The KfdK, under Frick's auspices, arranged its first major youth conference on [[Pentecost]] in 1930. It presented Nazi leaders [[Baldur von Schirach]], [[Goebbels]], [[Hermann Göring|Göring]], and [[Walther Darré|Darré]]. Referencing Weimar's "spiritual heroes" a resolution called for "strengthening German military will" and, in reference to the arts, "resistance against all populist harmful influences in the area of theater, literature and fine arts, and against alien architecture." The following Pentecost in 1931, saw a youth and cultural meeting in Potsdam, where Rosenberg gave a lectures on "Blood and Honor," and "Race and Personality" and Göring on the theme "Readiness to fight to protect our culture."
==Bibliography== ;Background history * Hildegard Brenner: ''Die Kunstpolitik des Nationalsozialismus''. Reinbek bei Hamburg 1963, [http://d-nb.info/450614182 DNB]. * [[Klaus Vondung]]: ''Die Apokalypse in Deutschland''. Munich 1988, {{ISBN|3-423-04488-8}}. * Jan-Pieter Barbian: ''Literaturpolitik im »Dritten Reich«''. Institutionen, Kompetenzen, Betätigungsfelder, Nördlingen 1995, {{ISBN|3-423-04668-6}}. * Wolfram Meyer zu Uptrup: ''Kampf gegen die „jüdische Weltverschwörung“''. Propaganda und Antisemitismus der Nationalsozialisten 1919-1945. Berlin 2003, {{ISBN|3-932482-83-2}}.
;Primary sources and documents * Alfred Rosenberg: ''Aufruf!''. in: Der Weltkampf 5 (May 1928), pp 210–212. * ''Nationalsozialistische Propaganda in der Münchner Universität''. In Frankfurter Zeitung, Evening Edition 25. February 1929, P. 2. * Reichsleitung/Kampfbund für deutsche Kultur (ed.): ''Schwarze Liste für öffentliche Büchereien und gewerbliche Leihbüchereien''. Berlin 1934, [http://d-nb.info/361524463 DNB]
;Research and monographs * Reinhard Bollmus: ''Das Amt Rosenberg und seine Gegner''. Studien zum Machtkampf im nationalsozialistischen Herrschaftssystem. Stuttgart 1970, [http://d-nb.info/456157557 DNB] (2. Aufl., Munich / Oldenburg 2006, {{ISBN|3-486-54501-9}}.) (One chapter of quantitative data based closely on source material) * Frank Wende (ed.): ''Lexikon zur Geschichte der Parteien in Europa''. Kröner, Stuttgart 1981, {{ISBN|3-520-81001-8}}. * Jürgen Gimmel: ''Die politische Organisation kulturellen Ressentiments''. Der „Kampfbund für deutsche Kultur“ und das bildungsbürgerliche Unbehagen an der Moderne. Münster / Hamburg / London 1999, {{ISBN|3-8258-5418-3}}. * Harald Lönnecker: ''„... Boden für die Idee Adolf Hitlers auf kulturellem Felde gewinnen“. Der „Kampfbund für deutsche Kultur“ und die deutsche Akademikerschaft''. In: GDS-Archiv für Hochschul- und Studentengeschichte, Vol. 6, edited by Friedhelm Golücke / Peter Krause / Wolfgang Gottwald / Klaus Gerstein / Harald Lönnecker, Cologne 2002, pp. 121–144.

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät | image = Provinssirock 20130616 - Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät - 01.jpg | caption = The band performing at [[Provinssirock]] in 2013 | alt = All four members performing on a stage. | image_size = | landscape = Yes | background = group_or_band | alias= PKN | origin = [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]] | genre = [[Punk rock]] | years_active = {{Start date|2009}}–2016 | label = [[Red Lounge Records]], [[Sony Music]] | website = {{ConditionalURL}} | current_members = Pertti Kurikka
Kari Aalto
Sami Helle
Toni Välitalo }} '''Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät''' ('''PKN''', {{Langnf||Finnish|"Pertti Kurikka's [[name day]]s"}}) were a [[Finland|Finnish]] [[punk rock]] band, formed in 2009 in a charity workshop for adults with [[developmental disabilities]]. They are the main focus of the Finnish documentary film ''[[The Punk Syndrome]]''. In 2015, they qualified for the finals of [[Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu 2015|Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu]], which they later won; they represented Finland in the Eurovision Song Contest 2015 but got knocked out in the semi-final. The band disbanded in December 2016 when guitarist Pertti Kurikka turned 60 years old and retired from playing punk rock.{{cite web|url=http://www.hs.fi/kulttuuri/art-2000005022200.html|title=Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivien viimeisellä keikalla Tapaninpäivänä oli hikistä, ahdasta ja tunteikasta eli aivan mahtavaa|date=27 December 2016|publisher=|accessdate=5 October 2017|language=fi}} ==History== ===Formation (2004-2012)=== Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät began in a workshop run by Lyhty, a charity for adults with developmental disabilities. In 2004, Pertti Kurikka, the future guitarist of the band, met organizer Kalle Pajamaa of Lyhty.{{cite web| title = Never mind the mall punks, here’s Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät!| author = Arttu Tolonen| work =Finnish Music Quarterly |date=June 2013| accessdate = 6 March 2015| url = http://www.fmq.fi/2013/06/never-mind-the-mall-punks-heres-pertti-kurikan-nimipaivat/}} Pajamaa, who remains manager of the band today, noticed Kurikka's potential and sought to establish a band based upon him.{{cite web| title = Nytpedia: Tällainen yhtye on Pertti Kurikan nimipäivät|trans-title=Nytpedia: This is what the band Pertti Kurikan nimipäivät is like| work =Nyt| date = 2 March 2015| accessdate = 6 March 2015| url = http://nyt.fi/a1305932608636| language = Finnish}} They worked on the band's formation over the next five years, and in 2009 the band made its debut. In 2009, Finnish director [[Pekka Karjalainen]] sought music performed by people with disabilities for the film ''[[Vähän kunnioitusta]]'',{{cite web| title = The Story of PKN, the Finnish punk sensation ready to rock Eurovision| work = Nyt| date = 3 March 2015| accessdate = 6 March 2015| url = http://nyt.fi/a1305933792584}} which tells the story of a young girl with a [[learning disability]] aspiring to live an independent and normal life. Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät is featured in the film with their first-ever [[Demo (music)|demo]]: "Kallioon!".{{cite web| title = Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät osallistuu Uuden Musiikin Kilpailuun| author = Arto Mäenpää| work =KaaosZine| date = 13 January 2015| accessdate = 6 March 2015| url = http://kaaoszine.fi/pertti-kurikan-nimipaivat-osallistuu-uuden-musiikin-kilpailuun/|trans-title=Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät takes part in Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu|language=Finnish}} The song became a hit, and the band soon discovered that they had a following outside the circle of disabled people. In 2012, their fame grew as they were the main subject of ''[[The Punk Syndrome]]'', a Finnish documentary film. The documentary, depicting the band's story from its outset to their first European tour, earned them a following in Scandinavia and Germany.{{cite web|last1=Hay|first1=Mark|title=A Finnish Punk Band with Learning Disabilities Is Going to Eurovision|url=https://www.vice.com/read/a-finnish-punk-band-with-learning-disabilities-is-going-to-eurovision-189|website=VICE|accessdate=4 March 2015|date=3 March 2015}} ===2014: Charity concert with Mr. Lordi=== In 2014, the band performed in a charity concert with [[Mr. Lordi]] of the Finnish rock band, [[Lordi]]. The charity concert was held in Rovaniemi on 23 May 2014 for benefit of the mentally-disabled community of [[Mozambique]] and the Lapland Metkat Association.{{cite web|url=http://www.kvtl.fi/fi/ajankohtaista/lisaa-ajankohtaisia/?nid=1173 |title=Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät point Mr. Lordi May Rovaniemi|publisher=Kvtl.fi |date=2014-02-28 |accessdate=2015-02-18 |language=fi}} Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät's bold and unusual take on Eurovision has been compared to that of Lordi, [[Finland in the Eurovision Song Contest 2006|Finland's 2006 Eurovision entry]] and the winner of [[Eurovision Song Contest 2006|that year's contest]].{{cite web| title = The Punk Syndrome: Band With Down Syndrome Applies for Eurovision| work = [[Sputnik (news agency)|Sputnik]]| date = 21 January 2015| accessdate = 6 March 2015| url = http://sputniknews.com/society/20150119/1017088930.html}} ===2015: Eurovision Song Contest 2015=== The band entered [[Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu]], Finland's national selection for [[Eurovision Song Contest 2015]] with the song "[[Aina mun pitää]]".{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1zcie_ykFqo|title=UMK15 // PERTTI KURIKAN NIMIPÄIVÄT: "Aina mun pitää"|publisher=Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu on Youtube. |date=2015-01-13 |accessdate=2015-02-18 |language=fi}} They entered the contest in order to raise awareness for people with Down's Syndrome.{{cite web|url=http://www.deathandtaxesmag.com/235838/punk-band-with-down-syndrome-looks-to-raise-awareness-in-eurovision-song-contest/ |title=Punk band with Down Syndrome looks to raise awareness in Eurovision Song Contest|publisher=deathandtaxes.com. |date=2015-02-02 |accessdate=2015-02-18}} On 7 February 2015, the band was one of the three acts from the first-semi finals to advance to the finals.{{cite web|url=http://wiwibloggs.com/2015/02/07/umk-2015-satin-circus-advance-to-the-final/77617/|title=UMK 2015: SATIN CIRCUS, PERTTI KURIKAN NIMIPÄIVÄT AND NORLAN EL MISIONARIO ADVANCE TO THE FINAL|publisher=wiwibloggs.com. |date=2015-02-07 |accessdate=2015-02-18}} On 28 February 2015, the band won Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu 2015, thereby becoming [[Finland in the Eurovision Song Contest|Finland's representative]] for the Eurovision Song Contest in [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] in May 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=pertti_kurikan_nimipaeivaet_win_umk_in_finland|title=Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät win UMK in Finland!|publisher=eurovision.tv. |date=2015-02-28 |accessdate=2015-02-28}} PKN was the first punk band to compete in Eurovision. PKN's Eurovision bid was noticed by the international media and covered, for instance, by the BBC,{{cite web|title=Finland punk band PKN set for Eurovision|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-31682196|website=BBC News|publisher=BBC|accessdate=4 March 2015}}{{cite web|title=Finnish punk band with a difference|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p02l4jrc|website=BBC World Service|publisher=BBC|accessdate=4 March 2015|date=2 March 2015}} ''The Guardian'',{{cite web|last1=Crouch|first1=David|title=Finnish punk band with a difference take a punt at Eurovision title|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/feb/27/finnish-punk-band-take-punt-eurovision-title|website=The Guardian|accessdate=4 March 2015|date=27 February 2015}} VICE and the Associated Press.{{cite web|title=Disabled punk rockers to compete in Eurovision Song Contest|url=https://www.yahoo.com/music/s/disabled-punk-rockers-compete-eurovision-song-contest-165229024.html|website=Yahoo! Music|accessdate=4 March 2015|date=1 March 2015}} [[Posti Group|Posti]] issued a PKN stamp on 11 May 2015, eight days before the first Eurovision semi-final in Vienna.{{cite web|title=Let's cheer on Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät to Eurovision victory|url=http://posti.fi/english/current/2015/20150428_perttikurikannimipaivat.html|publisher=Posti|accessdate=29 April 2015|date=28 April 2015}} ==Members== The band has four members: guitarist Pertti Kurikka, vocalist Kari Aalto, bassist Sami Helle and Toni Välitalo on drums. ===Pertti Kurikka=== Pertti Kurikka (born 26. December 1956 in [[Vihti]]){{cite web| title = Suomen euroviisuedustaja Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät pitää pissatauot ajallaan | author = Jouni K. Kemppainen| work = Kuukausiliite| publisher = ''[[Helsingin Sanomat]]''| date = 13 February 2015| accessdate = 16 March 2015 | url = http://www.hs.fi/kuukausiliite/a1305926871073| language = fi}} is the band's guitarist. He writes the music for the band and also some of the lyrics.{{cite web|url=http://kovasikajuttu.fi/en/topics/band-members |accessdate=March 7, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402123827/http://kovasikajuttu.fi/en/topics/band-members |archivedate=April 2, 2015 |title=Pertti Kurikka (guitar)}} He has released a spoken word cassette{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Kalevi-Helvetti-Kertoo-kummitusjuttuja/release/3369541 |title=Kalevi Helvetti - Kertoo Kummitusjuttuja (Cassette, Album) at Discogs |publisher=Discogs.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-25}} and a book{{cite web|author= |url=http://nyt.fi/a1305862570326 |title="Musta haamu tappaa" – Pertti Kurikan synkkä sivupersoona Kalevi Helvetti julkaisi kirjan - Kirjat - Nyt |publisher=Nyt.fi |date= |accessdate=2015-08-25 |language=fi}} of horror stories under the pseudonym Kalevi Helvetti. He also edits a [[zine]] called "Kotipäivä" ("Home Day").{{cite web| title = Suomen euroviisuedustajat henkilökuvissa | author = [[Rakel Liekki|Tiina-Rakel Liekki]]| work = Kioski| publisher = ''[[Yle]]''| date = 14 May 2015| accessdate = 17 May 2015 | url = http://erikoiset.kioski.yle.fi/jutut/1505-pkn/| language = fi}} Kurikka has been listening to punk for 30 years, but also listens to many other music genres ranging from classical to schlager and disco to children's music.{{cite web|url=http://www.kodinkuvalehti.fi/artikkeli/hyva_mieli/ihmissuhteet/pertti_kurikka_hei_vahan_kunnioitusta |title=Pertti Kurikka: "Idea Euroviisuihin osallistumisesta oli minun" | Kodin Kuvalehti |publisher=Kodinkuvalehti.fi |date= |accessdate=2015-08-25|language=fi}} He visits church regularly and plans to retire and stop playing music when he turns 60. He can also play the [[street organ]]. ===Kari Aalto=== Kari Aalto (born 25. May 1976 in [[Tampere]]){{cite web|author= |url=http://www.hs.fi/kulttuuri/a1432431999816?ref=hs-top4-3 |title=PKN:n punkkarit saivat kotimatkalla kuninkaallisen kohtelun: Ykkösluokka, kapteenin tervehdys, lahja henkilökunnalta - Euroviisut - Kulttuuri - Helsingin Sanomat |publisher=Hs.fi |date=2015-05-24 |accessdate=2015-08-25 |language=fi}} is the singer of the band and also writes most of their lyrics. He is a school friend of Kurikka.{{cite web|url=http://www.iltasanomat.fi/musiikki/art-1421987563526.html|title=Viisusuosikki Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät -tähtien koskettavat elämäntarinat: "Äitiä oli aina ikävä"|author=Maiju Majamaa|work=Ilta-Sanomat |language=fi}} He has his own talk show on Finnish local radio station Bassoradio.{{cite web|url=http://www2.ray.fi/fi/ray/ajankohtaista/euroviisupunkkari-kari-aalto-is%C3%A4nn%C3%B6i-taas-basson-ohjelmaa|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403001303/http://www2.ray.fi/fi/ray/ajankohtaista/euroviisupunkkari-kari-aalto-is%C3%A4nn%C3%B6i-taas-basson-ohjelmaa|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2015-04-03|title=Euroviisupunkkari Kari Aalto isännöi taas Basson ohjelmaa | ray.fi|publisher=|date=|accessdate=2015-08-25|language=fi}} He can play drums, bass and keyboards. He loves motorcycles, American cars, women and alcohol.{{cite web|url=http://www.iltasanomat.fi/viihde/art-1425705934758.html|title=PKN-laulaja Kari Aalto kertoo nolosta kokemuksesta Ray:n lehdessä – sai ravintolaan porttikiellon|author=Siina Leppä|work=Ilta-Sanomat |language=fi}}{{cite web|url=http://yle.fi/aihe/yle_stage/75302|title=YLE|work=yle.fi|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150221042750/http://yle.fi/aihe/yle_stage/75302|archivedate=2015-02-21|df=}} He listens to 1950s and 1960s rock, psychobilly, rockabilly, surf, doowop and also rap, heavy metal and folk.{{cite web|author=Noora Jussila |url=http://www.vihrealanka.fi/henkil%C3%B6t/onnen-p%C3%A4iv%C3%A4t |title=Onnen päivät | Vihreä Lanka |publisher=Vihrealanka.fi |date= |accessdate=2015-08-25|language=fi}} He does not listen to punk in his spare time, as nowadays it is his profession. ===Sami Helle=== Sami Helle (born 1973){{cite web|author= |url=http://www.hs.fi/kuukausiliite/a1305926871073 |title=Suomen euroviisuedustaja Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät pitää pissatauot ajallaan - Euroviisut - Kuukausiliite - Helsingin Sanomat |publisher=Hs.fi |date=2015-02-13 |accessdate=2015-08-25 |language=fi}}{{cite web|author=Maiju Majamaa |url=http://www.iltasanomat.fi/musiikki/art-1421987563526.html |title=Viisusuosikki Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät -tähtien koskettavat elämäntarinat: "Äitiä oli aina ikävä" - Musiikki - Ilta-Sanomat |publisher=Iltasanomat.fi |date=2015-01-24 |accessdate=2015-08-25}} plays bass in the band and also sings background vocals. As a child he lived in [[Boston]], [[New York City]], [[Paris]] and [[Antibes]], so he can speak fluent English. He is politically active as a member of the Finnish [[Centre Party (Finland)|Central Party]]{{cite web|author=Hilkka Säävälä |url=http://yle.fi/uutiset/keskusta_uhoaa_voittavansa_jo_euroviisutkin/7826248 |title=Keskusta uhoaa voittavansa jo euroviisutkin | Yle Uutiset |publisher=yle.fi |date=2015-02-24 |accessdate=2015-08-25}} and also as activist of ''Me itse'', an organization of disabled people.{{cite web|url=http://www.kvtl.fi/fi/me-itse/ajankohtaista/kasikynkka-projekti/puhujapankki/kokemuspuhujat-aakkosjarjestyksessa/sami-helle/|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20150311095343/http://www.kvtl.fi/fi/me-itse/ajankohtaista/kasikynkka-projekti/puhujapankki/kokemuspuhujat-aakkosjarjestyksessa/sami-helle/|deadurl=yes|title=Sami Helle - Kehitysvammaisten tukiliitto ry|date=11 March 2015|archivedate=11 March 2015|publisher=|accessdate=5 October 2017 |language=fi}} He wishes to become a municipal councillor of Helsinki and later a member of the parliament.{{cite web|url=http://yle.fi/ylex/uutiset/pkn-basisti_sami_helle_eduskuntaan_paasy_on_mun_haave/3-7844757 |title=YleX |publisher=yle.fi |date= |accessdate=2015-08-25 |language=fi}} ===Toni Välitalo=== Toni Välitalo (born 1982 or 1983) is the drummer and also the youngest member of the band.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.hs.fi/kulttuuri/a1425179182318 |title=Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät HSTV:n haastattelussa: "Tuli tunne, että nyt tulee Surun pyyhin silmistäni" - Euroviisut - Kulttuuri - Helsingin Sanomat |publisher=Hs.fi |date= |accessdate=2015-08-25}} He started playing drums at the age of six.{{cite web|author=Kirsikka Kiviniemi |url=http://www.iltasanomat.fi/euroviisut/art-1425344863581.html |title=PKN-viisurumpalin isä: Tällainen Toni oli lapsena - Euroviisut - Ilta-Sanomat |publisher=Iltasanomat.fi |date=2015-03-03 |accessdate=2015-08-25 |language=fi}} In addition to punk, he plays other genres such as [[jenkka]], blues and [[mazurka]]. His favourite music is [[Schlager music#Finland|Finnish schlager]].{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.hs.fi/kulttuuri/a1423199307743 |title=UMK-kilpailijat valmistautuvat iltaan: yksi takoo Katri Helenaa, toinen etsii kadonnutta ääntä - Euroviisut - Kulttuuri - Helsingin Sanomat |publisher=Hs.fi |date=2015-01-14 |accessdate=2015-08-25}} ===Kalle Pajamaa=== Disability director Kalle Pajamaa (born 1979) is the band's concert manager and arranges the songs for the band. He is affectionately called the fifth member of the band.{{cite web| title = Nimipäiväjuhlien järjestäjä| author = | work = [[Kouvolan Sanomat]]| date = 5 January 2013| accessdate = 16 March 2015| url = http://www.kouvolansanomat.fi/Takahuone/2013/01/05/Nimipäiväjuhlien_järjestäjä/201314/480| language = fi}} ==Discography== ===Compilation albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! scope="col" rowspan="2"| Title ! scope="col" rowspan="2"| Details ! scope="col"| Peak chart positions |- ! scope="col" style="width:3em;font-size:85%;"| [[The Official Finnish Charts|FIN]]
{{cite web|url=http://finnishcharts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Pertti+Kurikan+Nimip%E4iv%E4t|title=Discography Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät|publisher=Finnish Charts Portal. Hung Medien (Steffen Hung)|last=Hung|first=Steffen}} |- ! scope="row"| ''[[Kuus kuppia kahvia ja yks kokis]]'' | * Released: 7 December 2012 * Label: Airiston Punk-levyt * Format: [[Music download|Digital download]], [[Compact Disc|CD]] | 17 |- ! scope="row"| ''Sikakovapaketti'' | * Released: 2012 * Label: N/A * Format: Digital download, CD | — |- ! scope="row"| ''Coffee Not Tea'' | * Released: 2013 * Label: Constant Flux * Format: Digital download, CD | — |- !
